story:
I’m Morris Y. Matadi, a Liberian former child soldier and the Founder/Executive Director of the Initiative for the Development of Former Child Soldiers (IDEFOCS).  We are dedicated to the prevention of the recruitment of children and the re-recruitment of former child soldiers (FCS) for armed conflicts. We advocate, lobby, and network with other national and international organizations for the rehabilitation and reintegration of FCS (girls and boys) and women associated with fighting forces (WAFF) through the provisions of trauma counseling, technical and vocational skill training programs, agriculture, sanitation, academic  scholarship, and peace education. My campaign will impact others by creating peaceful living conditions for former child soldiers and the community by providing counseling services (e.g., PTSD) and educating and training FCS.  

If we do not succeed, then recruitment and the re-recruitment of FCS in Liberia by war-lords, who usually take advantage of the vulnerability of these FCS, will increase, and these soldiers will be recruited to fight to other countries. Subsequently, many FCS, having grown accustomed to violence from their intensive participation in the civil war in Liberia now will be left unskilled and unemployed. They will transform their former violent behavior into armed robbery and other criminal activity, and they will not be reintegrated into the Liberian community as a contributing member of society.

The Initiative for the Development of Former Child Soldiers (IDEFOCS) needs $20,000 to educate 60 former child soldiers with counseling, medical care, academic, technical and vocational training. The money will be spent as follows: school fees:  $125 a year per student (for 60 students) = $7,500; spending allowance:  $12.00 per student a month (for 60 students) = $8,640; counseling services:  $100 per month for one counselor for all students, or $1,200 per year; medical care: $1,500 for all students per year; and $1,160 for office use.  From the founding day of IDEFOCS we have worked with more than 1,000 former child soldiers and reintegrated them in our communities by providing jobs. Presently IDEFOCS is working with 75 former child soldiers who have not yet completed rehabilitation and reintegration. Fifteen of these FCS are receiving technical vocational training supported by community members and international students from around the world. With $20,000 IDEFOCS can educate more FCS and provide JOBS for them.

Please support IDEFOCS with this campaign to educate 60 former child soldiers. Your donation will help safeguard our communities.  Please give us the chance to live with our communities in peace because we deserve a second chance. Share the campaign with your family, community, friends and nation by making some noise for IDEFOCS.

story:
Thank you to everyone that has supported the event so far! 

And, don't worry, it's not too late to donate if you haven't already. AND, you can still claim any remaining perks with your donation! 

This page will be live until August 25th and will still accept donations.

Although we have reached our goal of $10,000 for the calendar fee, every additional donation helps make this event a success!  

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Our Story

Rock climbing is one of Canada’s fastest growing sports. Climbing unites communities and contributes to an active, healthy lifestyle among adults & youth.

To further the sport of climbing in Canada and help support Canadian athletes, we want to bring a World Cup climbing event to the city of Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

The 2-day event would be Eastern Canada's first chance to see World-Class climbing athletes perform in our city-center.

What we need

To hold the event, our organizing committee of 6 volunteers must raise $10,000 before August, 2012.

That’s just $2 from 5,000 people. If you love rock climbing or just want to support Canadian athletics and the Toronto community, please contribute and help make this happen!

The funds will be used to pay the International Federation of Sport Climbing’s calendar fee. The fee is required for our event to be recognized as an official, World Cup event. Once our event is officially recognized, we can begin reaching out to sponsors to fundraise for the rest of the event (including a climbing wall, venue rental, staffing, etc).

The $10,000 fee is non-refundable and given that we’re are just regular folks, volunteering our time, it would be great to have your help!

You can also send donations to the Alpine Club of Canada and request the funds to be directed to the CEC - Toronto World Cup 2013.

IMPORTANT: donations made through indiegogo are in USD

The Impact

If our goal is reached, we will be able to continue planning the World Cup climbing event.

The end result will be a great summer experience for all attendees. The event is sure to draw in crowds from across Canada and the USA.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you’re not able to contribute funds but would like to sponsor in kind or volunteer, please write us at info@torontoworldcup.com. We’d love to hear from you!

Tell your friends!

If you like this cause and want to help, please share this on facebook or twitter.

Thank you for your support! 

The World Cup Toronto 2013 Organizing Committee

For more information about the IFSC, visit www.IFSC-climbing.org

torontoworldcup.com

story:
Our Story

No matter what you call them - The iGeneration, Generation Me, The Millennial Generation - digital natives have educational needs that are much different from our own. In my Language Arts class at The Clinton School for Writers and Artists, many students speak the digital language so fluently that they can operate any kind of technology straight out of the box. Others have never had a computer at home and have rarely used one at school. And there is every range of student in between. The thing that they all have in common is that we are delivering them into a digital world where no matter where they come from or what kind of access to technology they’ve been exposed to, they will be required to speak the language of computers - a language that changes rapidly. The best thing for all students in this generation is complete preparedness for a working world that exists on the web, through social networking, in an ever changing landscape of the digital world. This project is about full immersion in the digital language. We truly believe this will help close the achievement gaps that exist not only in our school but in schools across the nation. This is an opportunity to prove that engaging students in the medium they are most comfortable in will help them see the value of their own literacy.

The Impact

Through this experimental curriculum, we want to show that immersion in the digital world for a core subject area, in this case Language Arts, will lead to higher student achievement in all subgroups. My classroom is the perfect place for this study, as I teach in one of the most diverse schools in New York City. The reading and writing workshop model will be combined with outcomes based assessment in a completely students centered environment.


Statistics for The Clinton School for Writers and Artists

  • We are a small school with less than 300 students.

  • Less than 5% of our students are English Language Learners BUT,

  • But almost 25% of our population have an Individual Education Plan and receive Special Education Services.

  • About 30% of our students’ families income falls below the poverty line.

  • While half of our students are white, a quarter are hispanic or latino, roughly ten percent are black, and about ten percent are Asian/Hawaiian/Pacific Islander.

What We Need and What You Get

The money raised from this project will be added to any funds raised from educational and environmentally conscious grants that we win for this project. The classroom will be filled with as many laptops and the best quality laptops that we can afford after fundraising but before school starts next year with enough time for the computers to arrive. We prefer Macbooks because they are more trouble-free and our school does not have a full-time technology teacher, but we will go with the best we can afford. The budget for the project as envisioned ideally is $55,000, but we'll do what we can with every dollar we earn. We made the goal of this project $20,000 dollars because we wanted a better chance of reaching the goal so that the fee paid to this website stays at 4%.


Also check out our perks.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can share this project with anyone and everyone you know and encourage them to donate and share it with anyone and everyone they know. This project will serve a school that doesn't have the budget necessary to do this on its own. The administration of our school is in full support of the project if we can fund it.

story:
Big thanks to everyone that participated in this campaign.  We were able to use this to spread the word to new supporters.  We also had many people that supported the campaign outside of IndieGoGo -- because of this, we came much closer to our goal than the numbers here show.  If you would still like to support our efforts to bring the first Peace Center to Sierra Leone, please visit www.thepeaceproject.com/donate  We're still offering the perks listed here for donations through July 15.

Thank you for joining hands with us. Stay tuned for updates.  PLUS:  On July 10th, we'll announce our 3rd Annual Peace Project Call-for-Artists. Find details at www.thewhole9.com/thepeaceproject-info.php

LAST YEAR

The Peace Project and thousands of creatives worldwide joined hands with the people of Sierra Leone, Africa in one of the most unique collaborations ever attempted, Operation Rise. On September 21st, World Peace Day, 10,000 pairs of crutches were distributed across the country to amputees, war victims, polio survivors, women and children -- some who had been crawling on the ground for ten years.  

   

THIS YEAR

We’ll build the first Peace Center in Sierra Leone.  The Peace Center is a multi-use facility that will provide critical skills training and educational programs designed to get people working and out of poverty as quickly as possible.  

INTRODUCING... 

Make Peace is a fundraising campaign that creates greater equality between donors and recipients.  Although many people in Sierra Leone can use a hand-up, they're not looking for a hand-out. We’ve turned traditional fundraising upside down and have invited everyone, including the most financially challenged in Sierra Leone, to participate.  As you’ll see by the video above, they’ve stepped up.

LOFTY GOALS?

We seek to raise a minimum of $50,000 (50% of the cost of the structure shown above). $100,000 will make this a reality.

GIVE NOW, GET LATER

No matter where you are, you'll get something in return. See the incredible list of incentives that have been donated by creatives who believe that if we share our resources, we can "make peace."  

 

Visit www.thepeaceproject.com/makepeace2012 to view photos of these perks, plus many others.

QUESTIONS?  Email thepeaceproject@thewhole9.com or call 310-836-4600.

Please share this on Facebook and Twitter and help us reach our goal and Make Peace!

For images of other perks, please visit: www.thepeaceproject.com/makepeace2012

story:
HELP PUT AN END TO DOMESTIC ABUSE!

At some point in their lives, 1 in 4 women will be a victim of domestic abuse. Needless to say, we have a lot of people to help!

My name is Annie. I am asking for your help to put an end to domestic violence by supporting OFFSPRINGS CHARITIES IN ROCHESTER, NY -- a not-for-profit organization committed to rebuilding the lives of families that are shattered by domestic abuse.

OFFSPRINGS CHARITIES offers various forms of support for women and their children so they can heal, rebuild their lives, and reclaim the peace in their homes they deserve.

Our goal is to help create sustainable change that will help break the cycle of domestic abuse. TOGETHER, WE CAN END DOMESTIC ABUSE AND HELP ENSURE THAT WOMEN AND THEIR CHILDREN HAVE A SAFE, PEACEFUL PLACE THEY CAN CALL HOME!

Thank you from all of us at Offsprings Charities, for helping us make this world a more peaceful and safe place to live, work and play -- today and in the future!

story:
I am creating this site because I wanted to share about an exciting opportunity that God has brought into my life.  I have decided to join the Campus Outreach staff in Birmingham, Alabama as an Executive Administrative Assistant for the next two years.

 

I first felt called to give my life to Christ last New Year’s Eve at a Campus Outreach global conference.  At the end of the conference, there was an opportunity to text the words “send me” to Campus Outreach staff in order to find out where there was a need for staff inside and outside of the United States.  I received an email a few weeks later telling me that there was a position available for me at the Global Resource Center in Birmingham, and I knew in my heart that God was calling me there.

 

                Campus Outreach specifically works with college students by building friendships, sharing the Gospel of Christ with them and teaching them how to grow in their faith.  The Global Resource Center helps enable staff to bring the Gospel to unreached students in Brazil, Thailand, New Zealand, Australia, South Africa and the United States.  As an Executive Administrative Assistant, I will work closely with the Global Resource Director, enabling him to focus intently on leading and equipping CO staff ministering to unreached people around the world.  This is also an amazing opportunity for me to grow professionally as well as personally in my walk with Christ.  I feel extremely blessed to have been offered this opportunity!

 

Lastly, I would be so honored if you would join my support team as a financial and prayer partner.  I am trusting that God will provide for me as I am raising support for the two years I will spend in Birmingham.  Please take some time to pray and consider how you might be involved.  I would love it if you would take some time to help me get the word out and share my link with your friends and family as well.  Thank you so much for your time and consideration; it really means a lot to me!

story:
SHS Track & Field Coaches are looking to set up a series of fundrasiers in an effort to resurface the High School track and purchase much needed equipment. We understand the track itself has become a community hot spot where many families, rec athletes, collegiate alumni and many others come to workout and stay in shape. Let's work together to restore the wear and tear of our facilities!

If we can each be inspired to pour back into this place we all once called home (almost literally for some of you!) then we can continue ensuring that the SHS track legacy lives strong, through your continued support and dedication.

We're considering an ALUMNI Relay Meet as fundraiser event #1. Who's got more ideas?

The Goal is $60,000.00

  1. Track Resurface & Repaint: $18,000.

  2. Pole Vault Repairs: $10,000.00

  3. SHS Hurdles: $500.00

  4. UCS High Jump Pit Package: $6,000.00

  5. Lynx Finish Line FAT Scholastic Package: $5,000.00

  6. Portable Discus Cages: $8,000.00

  7. Miscellaneous Track Equipment: $12,500.00


Thanks for your help!



Blessings!

SHS Hurdles: $500.00
UCS High Jump Pit Package: $6,000.00
Lynx Finish Line FAT Scholastic Package: $5,000.00
Portable Discus Cages: $8,000.00
Miscellaneous Track Equipment: $12,500.00


Thanks for your help! 



Blessings!

story:
In nearly 30 years of charitable work in Mexico, Project Amigo has learned that the ability to read and the opportunity to be formally educated are among the things most desired by rural children and youth, opening to them new worlds of personal enjoyment and economic opportunity. 

Since 2001 we have delivered nearly 400 “mini-libraries” to schools throughout western Mexico. Your contribution to this campaign will enable us to continue this work:

  1. A skilled local herrero (metal worker) will build-to-order a sturdy three-shelf metal bookcase
  2. 200 books— purchased new from a wholesaler in Mexico, written in varying levels of elementary Spanish, and written by mostly Mexican authors
  3. Will be delivered to a rural school in Colima state by volunteers from the United States and Canada assisting us in one of our two annual Literacy Work Weeks.

These Project Amigo “mini-libraries” are often the first “library” these schools have ever owned, and your contribution to this project could help change a life. Thank you!

 

Since 1986 Project Amigo has been helping rural children in Colima, Mexico achieve their highest potential by providing programs and services that promote literacy; fund their education (schooling in Mexico is not free after 4th grade); enable advanced career education; and keep them healthy along their path to a brighter future.

As a 501-c-3 non-profit charity, Project Amigo is entirely funded by voluntary contributions of friends like you (fully tax deductible in the United States). Read more about us at www.projectamigo.org and consider joining us in person for a Work Week this next year!

story:
Our Story:

My husband and i have been running an Adult Soccer Group in NYC for 4 years. We have over 1,500 members and are truly honored to provide them with the ability to play soccer without paying the crazy league fees.

After we had our little girl, Ali, we realized that the league fee's are nothing compared to kids soccer classes fees in NYC. Our goal now is to do the same for children as we did for adults.


So….


We are happy to present: BRAINY SPORTS!!!


The idea is to integrate sports with basic pre-school education.

We brought together some of the best educators and sport coaches in New York City with the objective of developing spectacular holistic soccer classes. As if this wasn’t enough, we are taking it further by making these the most affordable, high quality, toddler soccer classes in NYC! The fees for the classes will support the FREE CLASSES offered to kids that other wise would never get a chance to participate.


The Impact:

We will change the world one child at a time.

Brainy Sports has combined three of the most important aspects of Child Development:


1.       Mental - Brainy Sports Soccer classes seamlessly include, number, color, and basic concept development. (Read more about the importance of early childhood stimulation)


2.       Physical - Brainy Sports Soccer classes develop essential motor skills by including running, jumping, and more complex physical movements. (Articles on the importance of mobility in childhood)


3.       Social - Brainy Sports Soccer classes are designed to prepare your child for Kindergarten or Pre-School. Most children do not have practice in team work and social organization when they enter Pre-School; this makes the transition process very stressful on the child. These classes are designed to ensure your child has the social stimulation necessary to develop these skills. (Read more on social development)


What We Need:

The curriculum is already developed. So the funding we need is for:


1.       Equipment- These are more than just your basic soccer classes. So in addition to soccer gear we also need educational equipment. (example: Large Letters for the kids to jump over). The cost for the equipment is $600.


2.       Training- We need to pay for coach training. We estimate that we need at least 3 well trained coaches. The cost is $350 for the teacher and coaches.


3.       Website Development- A well put together website. The cost for what we need is about $1,500.


4.       Permits- Field Permits and indoor rentals. We have to pay for the whole season before any classes are ever planned. The cost for the summer permits is $1200 and $800 for fall.


5.       Insurance-Youth Sports Insurance. The cost is $600.


6.       Uniforms- Little t-shirts for the kids. This is important because it reinforces unity and team work. About $400 for the year.


7.       Promotions- Getting the word out about the new classes. This is the hardest and most expensive part. We have to be see over other organizations that have $100,000 ad budgets. We hope to start with a budget of $1,000.  


8.       Development- Other sport curriculum's, we would like to offer more than just soccer. We need to hire coaches with other sport knowledge and put them with an educator. About $1000 to develop a baseball, basketball, and football curriculum.

The total cost of the project is: $7450

About half of the classes will be free and the others only 1/3 of our competitors cost. As you can see we can not do this without community support. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the word out. Post this link to your social networks: http://www.indiegogo.com/BrainySports


THANK YOU:

How amazing is it that we are able to support each other this way, without getting the banks involved.

Thank You indiegogo.com, with your website you are really changing the world.

story:
Check Elevated Athletics Out In SLAM Magazine - http://bit.ly/YlYFn7

 

We Love Young Athletes.

We truly believe there is something special about seeing a young athlete grow, we thoroughly enjoy development. We want to support young athletes in all sports; from baseball, football, basketball, soccer, volleyball, lacrosse, swimming to tennis & golf. The truth is that if you have been young, you have been a young athlete.

 

But There Is "No" Place For Young Athletes To Go.

There are ton's of fitness centers & community centers all over the world, but if you are young and you have fitness and or athletic goals -- trying to find the space, as well as the expertise to help guide you to accomplish your dreams & goals couldn't be any more painful than it already is -- for the billions of young athletes out there in the world.

 

We Know - Your Fondest Memories of Athletics Happened In Your Youth.

Whether it was winning your first championship, finally getting your first dunk in a game, scoring your first touchdown, hitting your first homerun, or having your first winning season - you still remember every intricate detail about it and you have taken something from those experiences and applied it to your life, and as a result you lead a successful life.

 

Finally - Something The Young Athlete Can Call Their Own.

It's about time the young athlete had something they could call their home! It's time we made something that is innovative, super cool, and exclusive to the young athlete. Why are we still training out of places that really don't care about the young athlete? Young Athletes should be working with people in environment's that really truly care about their fitness & athletic goals!

 

Elevated Athletics: The New Platform For Young Athletes

Elevated Athletics is the new innovation for young athletes, we want to give young athletes what they need - so that they can achieve all of their fitness & athletic goals. 

 

 

We've selected the best people, and we are collaborating with the worlds best architects to craft the sexiest building built for two main reason's - to create a true platform for the young athlete, and to be the brand known for endless development!

 

Simply Put - It's All Here.

We all know that young athletes need a total solution so that they can improve, so why is everyone in the athletic training space divided? Shouldn't getting what you need as a young athlete be easy? For this very reason we made Elevated Athletics your complete solution - for every athlete.

 

Programs Are Essential - But Programs Built & Designed Just For You Is Freaking Awesome!

You guys can go right ahead and wave "Good-Bye!" to all those boring programs & services every community center, fitness center, club/travel team, trainer has. Three words "It's Your World!", we want to empower young athletes not dictate or control young athletes; so with our programs we started with what you guys love and that's getting better at your sport and competing!

 

Design Always Mattered - So We Collaborated With The Frank Lloyd Wright School of Architecture.

It's really unfortunate most fitness, training, and community center's across the world don't look super cool - we saw that and realized we had the opportunity to empower, and create something really special for young athletes. We knew that by collaborating with the Frank Lloyd Wright School of Architecture we weren't just going to be able to create a beautiful center for young athletes; we knew we had a special opportunity to impact the design community, and yet again empower, and inspire the most important people yet again - each and everyone of you guys!

Taliesin West: The Frank Lloyd Wright School of Architecture 

A "Real" Big Brother or Sister - Mentorship

When we started crafting out our mentorship program we knew we didn't want our athletes to have mentor's that were out of touch with their own fitness/athletic goals - so we created a mentorship program that allowed each athlete to be mentored by someone who was at a level they are en route to!

 

It's More Than Just Athletics - It's Life 
All We Need Is You

Sports is one of, if not the best metaphor for life, and our mission is to prepare young athletes to lead a healthy, active, and very inspiring lifestyle - forever. We start with the most important thing, and that's engagement. We are not focused on building a training center that is just a place for young athletes to meet up with friends, play pickup, & lift weight's.

 

All We Need Is You

With your help we will be able to:

  • Make some key acquisitions for our media & technology infrastructure (we want you guys to have an experience that is next to none, and we know just what we need to do it!)
  • Place our initial order's for our equipment (we are lean as heck - we don't need 100 treadmills)
  • Place our bid on select locations (we have a lot of sites to choose from, but we need to know which southwest city to go to, and how big we need to be exactly for our young athletes)
  • Ideally, fund any tenant improvements  (i.e. we are creating something that is gorgeous - "A great brand needs a great deal of investment in caring" - Steve Jobs)

 

You All Are The VOICE To The World - Show Them In Your Numbers!

 

Nothing great is ever accomplished in solitude. Recruit anyone you know will support our movement - this is for you guys! We can't wait to see this movement come full circle - IT WILL BE EPIC!

story:
My Story

My name is Vivian Torres and I need help to be able to fund my university studying in order to be who I want to be.


Since I can remember I have been wanting to study Engineering. I used to play with my dad's electronics devices, try to fix everything that was broken, pull apart all sort of things, fix the Christmas lights, the broken printers and many others things. I was just born to do it.


I was born in Colombia (South America) and proud of it, a country that as beautiful and inspiring as it is, it's also full of tough and heart-breaking stories, some of which, I, myself had to experience. They were all very hard lessons through which I, grew a better person.


I arrived in Australia in 2009 aged 17, thanks to an unmeasurable sacrifice from my family. I was leaving my family for the first time to come to a wonderful land where I had no family and no one I knew. I arrived with an unmovable determination, an incorruptible honesty and a burning wish to make my dream come true. I knew, since I left the airport back in Colombia, that there was no going back, no giving up. Australia and Engineering was (and still is) my dream and this is my chance, my once-in-a-life-time opportunity.



At the time of writing I hold a student visa (573) that states I was to finish a 2-year course at Holmesglen TAFE and then continue my studies to become an engineer at Deakin University (VIC).

This was my plan but unpredictable and terribly timed situations presented that stopped me from being able to afford the fees for university: an armed robbery that left me and my family traumatised, my mother was diagnosed with cancer and her business just stopped getting orders, my sister was badly bashed at school as a result of bullying and she had to change schools several times which put my parents in economical difficulties, I was admitted to hospital for a week for a nasty appendicitis, the list of careers on demand from the department of immigration changed dramatically and I was declined a sponsorship from my employer at the time because they couldn't meet all the requirements and I was diagnosed with major depression. 



The Impact

Despite all this and the fact that I work part-time for no more than 20 hours a week (which is what I am allowed to work) I managed to keep my school results to an average of 7.0

Is this why, I was motivated to write this letter, because the thought of not being able to continue studying and therefore see my dream shatter right before my eyes is just terrifying. I am a great student, a fantastic worker and an outstanding individual. I stand by my morals and my work ethic, I am committed to what I set my heart on and I am driven by my will and my determination.


What We Need & What You Get

I, hereby, pray that you help me make my dream come true, to do whatever you can and wish to do to help me be able to fund my studies for university. I am willing to demonstrate and prove all that I've said, I have proof of legal and medical documentation that supports all I have written. I genuinely want to stay in Australia and want to study Engineering. But I need your help.



Other Ways You Can Help

Everyone can help, tell your friends with generous hearts, spread the word, post it on facebook, tweet it, blog it.

It's in your hands to help me make my dream come true and together I know we can do it.

story:
About us

The Youth Jazz Ensemble is an integral part of the education and outreach branch of the Sun Life Financial Uptown Waterloo Jazz Festival.  Its mandate is to engage and educate youth in the art form of creating and performing jazz music and to provide them with opportunities to play not only smaller shows, but on the main stage of the festival itself. 

Through a series of intense workshops led by Education and Outreach Director Dave Mansell and instructors Duncan McLennan and Jason White, the participants will learn not only the basics of jazz theory and performance, they will also learn to apply them at a more advanced level.  Some of the challenges include writing and performing their own compositions and arranging their own versions of classic standards.  We also like to introduce fun ideas such as “jazz-ifying” music that is traditionally not performed in jazz settings.

 

What we need in terms of funding

Our budget this year is projected based on last year’s commitment of hours that the instructors put into the project. The instructors and ensemble also participate in Jazz For Kids which is additional commitment and preparation work.  We wanted to use crowd funding for the program this year because we believe it will show even greater support for the participants, which will be more than encouraging for them.

  • Funding goes directly to hire our instructors and guests speakers.
  • In addition to the instructors, one of the perks offered this year is the DVD production which requires the hiring of video/audio services.
  • Instructors are paid a fair wage for their time at industry standards.  Even still, the instructors always go above and beyond with regard to their time and commitment.

 

Community Impact

At the core of our our goals for education and outreach, we believe that engaging youth is the front line of building a healthy arts community.  One of the best ways to engage them is to allow them to flourish in an environment where they can not only learn new skills and enhance their craft, but have an opportunity to create something that they can truly call their own.  

It is also a major part of this program that they youth have an opportunity to see what life is like as a professional musician.  Since they are afforded a spot on the festival bill along side other professionals whom they admire.

Our feedback from past participants has been overwhelmingly positive and many of them intend to return as many years as they can.  This has been a great validation of the program we set out and its impact on youth enthusiasm for jazz.

story:
Summary

We are the Gay Straight Alliance of Southern Illinois University Edwardsville. It has become a tradition for us to go to the annual MBLGTACC conference.

"The Midwest Bisexual Lesbian Gay Transgender Ally College Conference is the largest LGBTA college conference in the nation. It is an opportunity for LGBTA students and their allies and advisers to meet in a safe and supportive environment to learn and discuss issues of importance to the LGBTA community and other communities."

Normally, going to this conference would not be an issue, but this year it is. Our university usually provides funds to student government to either approve or deny student organizations for traveling allocations. They were provided 20,000 dollars at the begining of the school year, but have somehow "run out of funds" very early on in the year. This means that our student organization can not recieve any money from the university to make it possible to attend the conference this year. Our organization normally depends on some of these funds to help our group travel to the conference, which this year, is taking place in Michigan.

This conference is the main event that our students look forward to all year. It is the event that most of our fundraisers go towards, and what we work hard for all semseter. Even with all of our fundraisers, we will not be able to raise enough money to go alone.

 

What We Need 

The very minimum that we need to be able to attend this year is 500 dollars. This money will go towards renting a van (and gas) to carry about 10-15 students from Southern Illinois University Edwardsville to Michigan State University where the conference is taking place.

Any remaining funds will be used towards costs of the hotel.

The Impact

All of the students in our organization are paying for their own registration ranging from $65-$75 per person. We know times are hard for everyone right now, so we are trying to help raise as much money as we can so that each student that wants to attend, can do so.

If we cant raise enough funds, this will be the first year in a very long time that we wont be able to make it to the conference.

We are trying our hardest with other fundraisers to help us raise enough funds for everyone in our student organization to go!

'The conference brings people from many walks of life together to address issues that affect themselves, the LGBTA community and our world as a whole'

By contributing, you are helping lgbt youth attend a conference where they feel safe and will learn about issues they may face, and listen to motivational/inspirational speakers.
 
Please help us out!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate any money, you can still help!

-use the "share tools" here on indiegogo to help raise awarness about our cause. help us spread the word so that maybe someone else can help us out!

share on facebook, twitter or tumblr, anything will help!
story_txt:
Summary
We are the Gay Straight Alliance of Southern Illinois University Edwardsville. It has become a tradition for us to go to the annual MBLGTACC conference.
"The Midwest Bisexual Lesbian Gay Transgender Ally College Conference is the largest LGBTA college conference in the nation. It is an opportunity for LGBTA students and their allies and advisers to meet in a safe and supportive environment to learn and discuss issues of importance to the LGBTA community and other communities."
Normally, going to this conference would not be an issue, but this year it is. Our university usually provides funds to student government to either approve or deny student organizations for traveling allocations. They were provided 20,000 dollars at the begining of the school year, but have somehow "run out of funds" very early on in the year. This means that our student organization can not recieve any money from the university to make it possible to attend the conference this year. Our organization normally depends on some of these funds to help our group travel to the conference, which this year, is taking place in Michigan.
This conference is the main event that our students look forward to all year. It is the event that most of our fundraisers go towards, and what we work hard for all semseter. Even with all of our fundraisers, we will not be able to raise enough money to go alone.

Any remaining funds will be used towards costs of the hotel.


The Impact
All of the students in our organization are paying for their own registration ranging from $65-$75 per person. We know times are hard for everyone right now, so we are trying to help raise as much money as we can so that each student that wants to attend, can do so.

story:
Short Summary

I'm a freshman at Bowdoin College in Maine, USA. I traveled to South Africa a couple of years ago and worked in various townships to renovate homes and install solar water heaters, as well as to educate school age children about HIV/AIDS prevention. This year, I've taken a class about the history of Apartheid and colonialism in South Africa, and will be taking an online course this spring through Omprakash, a volunteer organization that seeks to create responsible and informed volunteers. I hope to use what I learn in this course to then go to the village of Tafi Atome in Ghana, Africa to volunteer for ten weeks this summer. I'll be working with children, many of whom are former child laborers, to teach them English, and I will also be recording the oral histories of the villagers. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • The average airfare for a flight from Boston, Massachusetts to Accra, Ghana is about $1,200. 
  • Compassionate Journeys (http://www.compassionatejourneys.com/Compassionate_Journeys_Volu.html) will  organize either a home-stay for me, or a hostel-stay. For ten weeks, this will cost $950. You can look on the Compassionate Journeys website under the "Fees" section to verify the price for ten weeks. 
  • For donations of $25, I will send you a handwritten postcard from Ghana. For donations of $100, I will send ten people a black and white photo taken in Ghana that I'll send upon my return to the USA. For two people who donate $500, I will send five black and white photographs taken in Ghana as well as stories that I will record from the villagers. 

The Impact

Any donation you're willing to give me would be greatly appreciated!
  • Having volunteered in South Africa, I very much want to travel to Ghana to experience its culture and history. I'm fascinated by the lasting affects that colonialism has on the modern world, particularly in developing countries. By being able to travel there and experience these affects myself, I will be able to effect change in the best way possible.  
  • This is my passion. It is what I want to do for the rest of my life. Whether it be through diplomacy and international relations, through humanitarian work and law, I want to change peoples' lives for the better. I want to work in development, and I want to start on the basic, human to human level. I want to become a part of the Tafi Atome community and learn about its struggles and its history, but also about its rich cultural heritage.

story:
Hello, My name is Faustina. I'm a Ghanian. I discovered that I was HIV-positive six years ago. That year, my husband passed away from AIDS. I am now a widow with five children. Above is a picture of my children and I. In the past, I was cooking and selling food at the roadside. Unfortunately, the high rates of stigma towards people living with HIV caused my customers to stop buying food from me. This was the only way I was able to feed my family, pay for my children to go to school, and pay for my treatment. Since then, paying for these important parts of my family and I’s livelihood has been difficult.

Three years ago, I was trained as a Model of Hope to assist the nurse’s anti-retroviral unit of Ashaiman Poly-Clinic. A Model of Hope is a person who uses him or herself as an example for someone who has been newly-diagnosed with HIV to encourage them to expand their hope and adhere to their treatment. We also offer home-based care to those who are bed-ridden. I became a Model of Hope to encourage and support those who are having difficulties to accept their status or face stigma. I also took this as an opportunity to further my education in health care. At first, this work was voluntarily. Recently, the organization began distributing a small allowance to Model of Hopes, which is 130 GHC (~65 USD) per month. For me, this amount goes solely to my debt. I am not able to use it for food, school fees, or treatment costs. Thankfully, my mother has been able to help cover food costs for my children and I and provide us with a home to live in. 

I recently began schooling at Health Concern Ghana. I am now done with my first semester and beginning my second. I have been able to afford to pay 550 GHC (~ 275 USD) of the 1,050 GHC (~525 USD) due for my school fees this semester. My school does not provide any financial aid resources. The amount I have paid has been saved from working as a Model of Hope and resources from my friends and family. I now have 500 GHC (~250 USD) left to pay of my school fees. I also pay 8 GHC (~4 USD) each day for transportation. The semester will be 121 days. Therefore, I need 960 GHC (~480 USD) for transportation this semester.  In total, I need to raise at least 980 GHC (~490 USD) to complete my education.

Raising this money for my education is important to me, because after I graduate I will be able to begin my health care career. Once I am able to begin work, I will have the ability to pay for food for my family, schooling for my children, and the continuation of my treatment. any amount helps, small or large. Thank you and may God bless you.

sincerely,
Faustina

story:
Short Brief

The Culture Bus needs a motor and gearbox to get it on the road. The first stage of funding will help the dream come true.

ABOUT THE PROJECT

Australia has one of the richest living indigenous cultures in the world yet it is disappearing faster than most would like to admit. The Culture Bus will attempt to reach remote indigenous areas across Australia to document and archive indigenous knowledge, culture, language and ancient dreaming stories. The bus will be set up as a 4 wheel drive fully mobile sound proof recording studio that can travel where its needed most. The bus will also be used to inspire indigenous youth to reconnect with their elders and culture through remote music workshops.

The bare bones of the bus is a 4x4 Toyota Coaster which is in dire need of a facelift. The bus has been purchased but needs work. Stage one will see the bus transported to a mechanic and have a new engine and gearbox fitted to get it on the road. 

After the bus is roadworthy stage two of the project will commence. Stage two will turn the bus into a mobile sound/dust proof studio. A fully functional studio will be built by a team of specialists once further funding has been raised.

Help keep indigenous culture alive!



STAGE ONE FUNDING - GETTING THE BUS ON THE ROAD

So basically the bus has been purchased and is ready for its conversion. The bus needs a lot of mechanical work so stage one of the project will provide the funding for that. The money will buy a reconditioned motor and gearbox and get all the essential mechanics ready to make the bus a reliable and a super tough desert dweller. Once this work has been completed the bus will go through the registration process and then be ready for the road. The next step is stage two, which will start with the build of a mobile studio in the bus.

STAGE ONE FUNDING BREAKDOWN

Here's a brief overview of what it will cost to get Stage One on the road:

Reconditioned motor $10,000

New gearbox $3000

Brakes $1300

Registration/third party approx $1500

Parts etc $1200

Mechanical work $3000


STAGE TWO FUNDING AND FOLLOW UP

After stage one is completed further funding will be raised to turn the bus into a mobile sound recording studio. The back two thirds of the bus will be replaced with a fully sound and dust proof room to house the studio in. After this the studio room will be built and equipped with mobile recording equipment ie. microphones, monitors, computer (music software), sound card etc. Movie editing software will also be placed on the computers with the ability to edit and produce film. 

The bus will also house a large solar array on the roof as well as a substantial battery bank and powerful inverter to run the studio in remote locations.

The bus recording room will be set up in a way as to enable elders to view their country when recording. This will be done by installing double glazed panoramic landscape windows on either side of the studio. This will have the benefit of getting the elders to feel close to their homelands when telling stories or singing songs. The studio will avoid the clinical approach and aim to create a comfortable and creative environment for those recording in it. Inside the studio a camera will be installed to help document the person/persons talking as to aim in documenting the process. Also the studio will have to capability to multi-track bands to and will house a variety of equipment to make this possible. On the outside of the studio a stage box featuring external xlr connectors will be present making it possible to also record live bands at community events. There will also be outside power points on the bus to enable it to become an outdoor power supply to.

The bus will then hit the road on its mission to record and document indigenous culture by means of gathering stories, language and songs. The bus will also be used to record music workshop projects with youth across remote communities. 

The bus will team up and partner with indigenous art galleries, local schools, local councils and local indigenous groups and individuals.


Who Can Use the Bus?

The bus will be involved in its own funded projects but it will also be available for other community projects with similar goals. From return to country trips, to remote workshops to teaming up with art galleries across remote Australia, the bus will spend its life where its needed most. The bus will be available at a minimum cost as to keep up with running and admin costs.


STAGE 3 FUNDING - ON THE ROAD


Stage three will see the Culture Bus hit the road. The Culture Bus will not only be used for its own documenting and recording projects with elders and youth across the desert, but it will also be available for hire for other worthy community projects. The bus would be available for hire with or without a driver (bus licence needed). As there are costs associated with running such a bus there will be a fee associated with hiring it. Costs however will be kept fair as  to make the bus available to all groups and projects.


WHY BUILD IT?

Over the years I've worked across Australian in remote areas in makeshift studio's. Some have been extreeme! I've setp up in old toilet blocks, in abandoned youth centres, in lounge rooms of motels and even on remote beaches with crocodiles (big ones too!). In my travels I've noticed three main factors. 

One: A lack of places and resources to record in and around a remote community.

Two: A lack of knowledge and skills in communities on how to document the many stories present. 

Three: Many of the last of the ancient aboriginal story tellers who hold vitally important dreaming stories and cultural knowledge are dying without their stories being documented.

The sad fact is that although these elders hold such important knowledge, many of the youth ie grandsons/granddaughter, have limited interest in their culture. Their are still elders living today who are "first contact" ie. where born in the bush and had no idea of white man or western culture until they walked in from the bush. These stories and people need to be documented. Its of vital importance for all Australians both aboriginal and non-aboriginal. 

After many years of oppression and cultural degradation through colonial culture at times todays generations often depressed and disempowered and have lost direction and a sense of meaning within their own society. Its sadly more common today seeing youth more interested in westernised objects such as smart phones, or just drinking their lives away in response to their situation.

There is a dire need to document this ancient culture's songlines and stories so as to not only keep the culture alive, but to also preserve it for future generations to listen to and re-learn in the future. Their is also a real need to reconnect the youth with their culture through music and film projects so as to form bridges between these two worlds to help rekindle and interest in their own history.


WHO IS MONKEY MARC ?

Indigenous Workshop and Recording

Monkey Marc is a producer/sound engineer. He has worked in remote aboriginal communities doing workshops with indigenous youth and elders for over 13 years. He has pioneered the concept of his Transfer of Knowledge projects across remote Australia with great success and produced such compilations as Red Sand Culture VOL 1 and VOL 2. He has worked in over 30 indigenous communities in every state of Australia and has extensive experience in the field.


Music

Monkey Marc has also toured the world extensively with his band Combat Wombat and his solo act Monkey Marc. He has produced music for the likes of UK legend Roots Manuva and Soom T and many more. He pioneered the use of vegetable oil in vehicles and traveled Australia on vegetable oil in 2000. He co-founded Labrats Solar Sound System with Izzy Brown and now co-runs one of Australias largest solar powered sound systems i.e. DIY Hi Fi with Phil Boutle and Richard Allen. He runs his converted shipping container recording studio on solar where he produces most of his music.

story:
Someone stole more than $600 of Joe's daughter's girl scout cookie money.

A police report has been filed but getting this little's girl money back from the perpetrator isn't likely to happen.

What can you do to help?

Please make a donation, no amount is too small. 

Any and all donations are greatly appreciated.

If you should claim a perk, it will ship within 2 business days. Those claiming perks outside of the United States, please include an additional $15 (USD) for shipping which will include a tracking number.

Feel free share this on Tumblr, Facebook, Twitter, e-mail and other social media outlets.  

Thank you.

Those claiming perks outside of the United States, please include an additional $15 (USD) for shipping which will include a tracking number.Feel free share this on Tumblr, Facebook, Twitter, e-mail and other social media outlets.  Thank you.

story:
Petit Zarafa™ is the first play-based multi-language learning subscription website for little ones ages 2 and up.

Petit Zarafa™ will offer hands-on activities in art, cooking, nature, music, imaginary play and numbers & letters, in several languages. The activities are easy to set up, easy to clean, and take anywhere from a few minutes, up to an hour. The first languages to be offered are: Arabic, Chinese, French, Spanish, and English as a second language.

Members will receive monthly play planners richly illustrated with video and sounds, and will become part of a global community of like-minded parents inspiring their little ones to learn languages while having fun! 

With each subscription, members will digitally receive the following vibrant content:

  • Monthly language planners
  • Up to 30 play-based activities per month
  • Video demonstrations and sound clips
  • Template downloads
  • Passport to track learning 
  • Book recommendations
  • Forum and discussions



When a child is playing, it is the perfect time to learn. Development of fine and gross motor skills, intellectual development as well as imagination, creativity, self-esteem and independence allows a child to create a deep connection with the world.

To help a child learn vocabulary in multiple languages, we structure hands-on activities within a context of play, making it fun for the child to think about, talk about, apply, and play with new words.  Children need to learn words playing, not as stand alone words that come and go. 

Recent scientific research shows that children who speak two or more languages have multiple advantages:

  1. They become smarter
  2. They build multitasking skills
  3. They make strong emotional ties with their parents
  4. They are socially more insightful




We are the design team behind Zid Zid Kids, makers of worldly handmade collections of playthings for children since 2003. 

As designer, our very foundation approach is based on play. A colorful range of products from playful animal cushions, to embroidered poofs, to handmade ballerina slippers and more, have been at the heart of our passion for the past 12 years. Here is a sample of honors we have received for our work:

Our goal is to make the creative multi-lingual world of Petit Zarafa™ a reality and here is what we need to make it happen: our budget is short of $20,000 to be used in the following way:

  • Production of 300 videos to demonstrate our activities (a video for each activity and for each language)
  • Initial website development and implementation

In return for your generosity we are offering an array of perks and rewards, and you will be included in the Petit Zarafa™ journey, helping us make this dream a reality.


Whether you are willing to contribute financially or not, you can head over to our website and sign up for our newsletter to receive updates on progress and fun free teaser content.

Also, you can follow us on Facebook, Twitter, or Pinterest to be included in the journey, as well as share the page with your friends and family! Thank you so much for joining us! 

LEARNING-RELATED QUESTIONS

How will my child learn?
By using a play-based approach to learning a new language, your child will be practicing vocabulary words alongside basic developmental skills used in hands-on creative activities such as cooking, dancing and imaginary play.

What makes Petit Zarafa unique from other language learning programs?
Our approach is the only one combining both language-learning and hands-on play, specifically designed for busy parents, caregivers and children. We make learning languages fun!

What if I don’t speak the language? Do I need to speak the language?
There is no previous language experience required. In the PZ program, we provide vocabulary pronunciation paired with the cultural context for each word, making it easy to learn and follow along. We also see this approach as an opportunity for you to learn with your child!

Will there be a pronunciation guide?
Yes, each word will be phonetically written and illustrated with a friendly sound clip (not a robot!) to give a full effect.

What if I can’t keep up with the schedule?
Our activities are spread over the month and designed with busy parents in mind. Monthly vocabulary words are kept at a minimum with full support coming from multiple activities. We have designed the curriculum so you are able to focus on each word paired with an activity of your choosing. The idea is to keep it fun and enjoy the process!

How many words will my child learn?
Our curriculum is designed to maximize the context of learning and focus on quality over quantity. Your child will be introduced to up to 180 words in a year with the option of doing more.

How can we best practice the language once we begin?
Our activities are designed for parents on the go, giving you and your child the time to absorb each new word. Once a few activities have been completed, strive to repeat the learned words when in new situations. Practicing while having fun is the key. We love singing silly songs while driving, using the words while we brush our teeth and practicing during other daily moments.

Why hands on play? It's time consuming!
Hands-on play involves just this, hands on! It might seem time consuming at the beginning, but we strongly encourage you to play with your child and become a part of the learning process. This playful learning process is a bonding opportunity. Keep in mind, our activities only take about 5 minutes to 1 hour, so they fit easily into a busy schedule and are well worth the investment.

My child is 8. Is he too old for this?
Our program is geared towards toddler and preschoolers, yet the activities can be adapted to fit the needs of an older child or sibling.

Who is this program designed for Parents, caregivers, nannies, grandparents?  All of the above! We’ve designed the program so it can easily fit into all levels.

How can I track progress for my child?
As a member, you will have access to a ‘learning passport’, which enables you to easily track your child’s progress with the opportunity to share your child’s milestones with other members. 

SUBSCRIPTION-RELATED QUESTIONS

How much will the subscription cost?
The Petit Zarafa program is $12 for a monthly subscription.

Can I try it for free?
Of course, we offer a free one-month trial to anyone anywhere.
story_txt:

With each subscription, members will digitally receive the following vibrant content:
Monthly language planners
Up to 30 play-based activities per month
Video demonstrations and sound clips
Template downloads
Passport to track learning 
Book recommendations
Forum and discussions

story:
About CVSOM:

Hello potential contributors and lovers of music! The Castro Valley School of Music is a new music school in Castro Valley, CA in the San Francisco Bay Area. Our mission here is make music education available to everyone who has ever wanted to learn how to play an instrument, sing or read music. 

About 8 months ago, Shane Sharkey, the owner of a music production company called Big Toe Audio, decided it would be a great idea to start music lessons at his production office. He found some great music instructors with tons of experience touring, recording and teaching. Slowly but surely business grew and before we knew it, we had out grown the office space. We recently found a new building with plenty of space and The Castro Valley School of Music was born.

The new Castro Valley School of Music provides instruction for both children and adults. We currently offer:

  • 8-week group classes with drums, piano, bass and guitar
  • Private lessons with drums, saxophone, vocals, piano, bass and guitar
  • An after school program where kids can come and learn about music, album making and can watch documentaries
  • Recitals where students can show off their new skills
  • Rehearsal space for bands and singers
  • A summer music camp in July and August (for children only)

                                   


Castro Valley is a diverse and artistic community and we are confident that the music school will be a perfect fit for its residents and the rest of the Bay Area. The biggest obstacle we are facing are the enormous start-up costs associated with a business this large and this is where you come in.

Where We Need Your Help:

In order for this school to be as amazing as we know it can be, there are a few things we need your help with to get everything up and running:

  • Labor fees
  • Rent
  • Demolition
  • Construction
  • Sound System
  • Signage
  • Marketing
  • Instruments
  • Furniture
  • Video Games & Consoles

Whether we reach our goal or not, every little bit helps. We want this school to be the best it can be. The more help we get, the faster The Castro Valley School of Music will be up and running at full steam.

We have many perks to choose from, for both musicians and those who support music education. Feel free to take a look. No donation is ever too small.

The Impact:

The importance of music goes very unnoticed. Music classes are being cut out of schools left and right, leaving children with little opportunity to ever pick up an instrument or learn about the wonders of music. 


The Castro Valley School of Music will have such an amazing impact on the community and Bay Area.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Help spread the word about our school! We definitely understand that times are tough, so anything as simple as a referral would be greatly appreciated.

story:
Peace be upon you!!!

I am excited to report that I have been accepted in the Master’s program for the Fall 2014-15 semester at the School for International Training (SIT) in Brattleboro, Vermont.  This will give me the opportunity to further my studies in the areas of trauma healing, intercultural sensitivity, international management and a variety of other subjects. I will study 3 months on campus in Vermont and 6 months doing an internship in one of the leading international organizations in the field of conflict management and resolution.

I have been awarded a partial scholarship.  I also plan to have work-study job on campus. However this will only cover a small portion of the tuition. Friends in VT have agreed to provide room and partial board but I have to pay for, some meals, a living stipend, transportation, communication costs, books and health insurance.  Therefore, I am respectfully requesting your assistance to help empower me to achieve my goals.

I only have until June 22, 2014 to come up with the balance of $14.780.  Every penny it will bring me closer to my goal.  Whatever you can afford will be appreciated.   

I don’t like having to ask for donations.  Having lived through wars both in Palestine and Iraq, I have a personal desire and interest in resolving disputes and in bringing peace to the world.  However, I face serious obstacles to pursuing my dream, including a physical and economic siege on my land and my people, political obstacles, social injustices, a lack of democracy, and a denial of other basic human rights.In exchange for your support I am willing to come and speak to your organization and do radio and TV interviews on behalf of your organization.

Your financial support will have an impact that extends far beyond me as an individual..Your investment in my education is not only an investment in my future, and the future of the Palestinian people, but in the prospects for a global peace.As a Palestinian living in the Gaza Strip, I have both a professional and a personal interest in learning new methods of addressing intercultural conflict. I have searched very hard to find an academic institution that offers programs which focus on trauma healing, intercultural exchange and programs that bring people together from around the world who  are working hard for finding solutions to these thought-provoking challenges.

You will provide me the opportunity to develop Trauma Healing skills that will help me to create a more hopeful future for myself and for my people.  If you are unable to send a donation, then please consider sharing this request with others who may be willing to help. 

Final budgeting:

SN

Item

Cost

1

Remaining Tuition

$10,945

2

Meals

1,000

3

Stipend for 3 months 

$1,350

4

Transportation and communication

$1000

5

 Health insurances

$485

  Total Needed

$ 14,780

If you will be helping me with the other expenses, you may send the money electronically as follows: 

Account # 381039524234 

Routing number:

021200339 (paper & electronic)

026009593 (wires)

 Aymin Nijim

354 Summit Ave., Hackensack, NJ  07601

If you prefer to send your donation directly to the school, you may write a check marked “Ayman Nijim – Tuition” in the memo and mail it to:

SIT Graduate Institute, 1 Kipling Rd., PO Box 676, Brattleboro, VT  05302

-   If you have questions or require further information, including copies of my acceptance letter, financial aid information or anything else, please let me know.aymanijim@gmail.com , or:

-  Cell phone number: 857-654-8914

-  Skype Address: ayman.nijim

-  Facebook name: Ayman Nijim

-  Latest TV interviews:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1r1T4FMuGGM

-  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RNEAnLkKUTs

With your assistance I feel confident that I will achieve my goals to further my education and the safe future of my people. Thank you in advance for whatever help you are willing to offer.

All the best,

Ayman Nijim

Olympia, Washington, 2012


Afaq Jadeeda Association , Gaza strip.

Speaking at University of New Mexico

story:
Hello.  My name is Matt Damadeo.  I am part of  team of individuals who are dedicated to making a difference in the world.  This week we had over 50 individuals make a pledge to raise $125,000, in 7 days, for St. Jude's Children's Hospital.  We are asking for your help.

The mission of St. Jude's Children’s Research Hospital is to advance cures, and means of prevention, for pediatric catastrophic diseases through research and treatment. Consistent with the vision of their founder Danny Thomas, no child is denied treatment based on race, religion or a family's ability to pay. 

Here are a few facts about St. Jude's:

- Families never receive a bill from St. Jude for treatment, travel, housing and food – because all a family should worry about is helping their child live.

- Treatments invented at St. Jude have helped push the overall childhood cancer survival rate from 20 percent to more than 80 percent since it opened in 1962.

- St. Jude has helped increase the survival rates for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) from 4% before opening in 1962 to 94% today.

- St. Jude is where doctors send their toughest cases because St. Jude has the world’s best survival rates for the most aggressive childhood cancers.

- The daily operating cost for St. Jude is $1.9 million, which is primarily covered by individual contributions.  For this reason, 100% of all money donated, is going straight to St. Jude's Hospital.

Every single pledge that is made here, no matter how big or small, will make a difference.  Cancer is one of the leading causes of death among us and it has probably affected you or someone you know.  I personally lost my Aunt to Cancer a few years ago and remember how hard it was. 

In my mind, the only thing worse than having to watch a child face cancer would be having to face it alone.  Since St. Jude's never turns a child away, no one has to be alone.

If you believe in St. Jude's vision of a cancer free world, and would like to do your part, please make a donation today .  If we all work together, we will reach this goal.

story:
Welcome to TriStar, Inspiring Greater Achievement Through Higher Altitude

TriStar is a registered 501(c)3 non-profit organization that uses flyable aircraft in educational and experiential programs to inspire students into STEM fields and aerospace related careers.  TriStar also supports other charitable groups with operational jet aircraft. 

We encourage students to engage with the STEM fields: Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math by providing an unforgettable aviation experience that complements the aviation and aerospace related curriculum in which they may already be engaged in school!  For children not already bitten by their class work, a TriStar experience can provide the spark that drives kids to succeed in school, pursue college and ultimately find a job in the STEM fields.   TriStar’s ultimate success is helping kids explore and achieve more than they thought possible.

We need funds to renovate the space and install full-motion flight simulators at the Kansas City Downtown Airport.

Once the simulators are in place, we can welcome groups of students to our facility for an aviation experience that makes their classroom curriculum come to life!  

TriStar partners with and is a resource to museums, schools, experiential exhibits,other STEM education initiatives and more to maximize our impact.  We are also building relationships with several large corporations and foundations to advance STEM Education.

The TriStar team is passionate about inspiring a new generation of scientists and engineers.  We are highly qualified for this mission and have already accomplished a great deal towards our vision.  We hope that through crowd funding can help us reach the rest of the way.  

TriStar's Homepage

TriStar's Fundraising Goal

To install the simulators, we need funding to renovate a historic facility at 10 Richards Road on the Kansas City Downtown Airport.  This historic space, once a TWA headquarters building and maintenance facility with offices for aviation legend Howard Hugheswill now invite young students to meet pilots and engineers, see technology in action, and reinforce their classroom lessons with a real aviation experience.

Of the approximately $385,000 needed, TriStar has raised $135,000 as well acquired our initial aircraft and flight simulator.  Preliminary engineering studies have been completed to provide initial cost estimates.  Donated funds will help pay for final detailed construction drawings, renovation of the space, HVAC and electrical distribution.   Our goal is to raise $50,000 through the amazing power of crowd funding.  Every dollar goes towards renovating the simulator building, or providing the perks.  For donating, we have several donor perks available, in addition to the satisfaction that every dollar goes toward inspiring students to engage in STEM fields!

Click here for other ways to help TriStar.

The Impact

The importance of STEM education has been gaining recognition and support. Visit the U.S. Department of Education's STEM Page and check out Project Lead The Way (PLTW). TriStar aims to be a big part in that effort both locally and nationally.  We want to be on-call aviation education and experiential resource able to take the mission into the air through flyable aircraft.

Although this campaign is specifically directed at installing our full-motion simulators, the success of this project will contribute to the success of our other programs, using our flying aircraft to actually take students on a flight.  Over time, we will also use these aircraft to do other charitable missions, such as Veterans' Honor Flights, Make-A-Wish, airshows, etc. Although most of our impact will be in the Kansas City area, our flying aircraft give us a national reach.  


TriStar's Values

  • Business-minded, purpose-driven management
  • Transparent business and financial operation
  • Proactive communication & relationship management
  • Good stewardship of donations and gifts
  • Community-based, accretive partnerships driven by shared success

TriStar's Accomplishments

The TriStar team has already made great accomplishments, an indicator of our passion and capabilities to make things happen.  We own two jet aircraft and a full-motion, professional-grade simulator.  The L1011 pictured here is being restored and will make its ferry flight to Kansas City soon:

 N91011, a 1983 Lockheed L-1011 TriStar

N999BW, a 1967 British Aircraft Corporation BAC1-11

BAC1-11 Simulator

This is the full-motion simulator, currently located in the UK, that will be installed at our facility in Kansas City, MO.  It uses complicated electronics, hydraulics, and software to provide the occupants with an amazingly life-like experience.  Students will learn about all the technology that goes into the simulator and the range of job fields available to them beyond pilot and crew that are  There’s a forecast shortage of new graduate with the needed skills; the TriStar mission is important to the kid and to a range of industries that support the aviation and aerospace industries.

The Simulator Space

Here are the initial construction drawings:


We have already been working with the design engineers, architects and construction firms that can complete our vision once the funding is in place.

Other Ways You Can Help

Learn more at our homepage! TriStar's Homepage, TriStar's How to Help Page

Like us on facebook! TriStar's Facebook Page

Follow us on Twitter! TriStar's Twitter Feed

Don't forget to use Indiegogo's share tools to spread the word about this opportunity to advance STEM Education!

Notes

TriStar is a 501(c)(3) non-profit company.  Check with your tax adviser for deductibility.

*Donor plaques will remain on the aircraft for as long as the aircraft is utilized by TriStar
story_txt:
Welcome to TriStar, Inspiring Greater Achievement Through Higher Altitude
TriStar is a registered 501(c)3 non-profit
organization that uses flyable
aircraft in educational and experiential programs to inspire students into STEM fields and
aerospace related careers.  TriStar
also supports other charitable groups with operational jet
aircraft.  
We encourage students to engage with
the STEM fields: Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math by providing an
unforgettable aviation experience that complements the aviation and aerospace
related curriculum in which they may already be engaged in school!  For children not already bitten by their
class work, a TriStar experience can provide the spark that drives kids to
succeed in school, pursue college and ultimately find a job in the STEM fields.
  TriStar’s ultimate success is helping
kids explore and achieve more than they thought possible.
We need funds to renovate the space
and install full-motion flight simulators at the Kansas City Downtown Airport.
Once the simulators are in place, we
can welcome groups of students to our facility for an aviation experience that
makes their classroom curriculum come to life!  
TriStar partners with and is a
resource to museums, schools, experiential exhibits,other STEM education
initiatives and more to maximize our impact.  We are also building
relationships with several large corporations and foundations to advance STEM
Education.
The TriStar team is passionate about
inspiring a new generation of scientists and engineers.  We are highly
qualified for this mission and have already accomplished a great deal towards
our vision.  We hope that through crowd funding can help us reach the rest
of the way.  TriStar's HomepageTriStar's Fundraising GoalTo install the simulators, we need
funding to renovate a historic facility at 10 Richards Road on the Kansas City
Downtown Airport.  This historic space, once a TWA headquarters building and
maintenance facility with offices for aviation legend Howard Hugheswill now
invite young students to meet pilots and engineers, see technology in action,
and reinforce their classroom lessons with a real aviation experience.
Of the approximately
$385,000 needed, TriStar has raised $135,000 as well acquired our initial
aircraft and flight simulator.  Preliminary engineering studies have been
completed to provide initial cost estimates. 
Donated funds will help pay for final detailed construction drawings, renovation
of the space, HVAC and electrical distribution. 
 Our goal is to raise $50,000
through the amazing power of crowd funding.  Every dollar goes towards renovating the simulator building, or providing the perks.  For donating, we have several
donor perks available, in addition to the satisfaction that every dollar goes
toward inspiring students to engage in STEM fields!
Click here for other ways to help TriStar.The ImpactThe importance of STEM education has been gaining recognition and support. Visit the U.S. Department of Education's STEM Page and check out Project Lead The Way (PLTW). TriStar aims to be a
big part in that effort both locally and nationally.  We want to
be on-call aviation education and experiential resource able to take
the mission into the air through flyable aircraft.
Although this campaign is
specifically directed at installing our full-motion simulators, the success of
this project will contribute to the success of our other programs, using our
flying aircraft to actually take students on a flight.  Over time, we will
also use these aircraft to do other charitable missions, such as Veterans'
Honor Flights, Make-A-Wish, airshows, etc. Although most of our impact
will be in the Kansas City area, our flying aircraft give us a national reach.  TriStar's Values
Business-minded, purpose-driven management
Transparent business and financial operation
Proactive communication & relationship management
Good stewardship of donations and gifts
Community-based, accretive partnerships driven by shared success
TriStar's AccomplishmentsThe TriStar team has already made great accomplishments, an indicator of our passion and capabilities to make things happen.  We own two jet aircraft and a full-motion, professional-grade simulator.  The L1011 pictured here is being restored and will make its ferry flight to Kansas City soon: N91011, a 1983 Lockheed L-1011 TriStarN999BW, a 1967 British Aircraft Corporation BAC1-11
BAC1-11 SimulatorThis is the full-motion simulator,
currently located in the UK, that will be installed at our facility in Kansas
City, MO.  It uses complicated electronics, hydraulics, and software to
provide the occupants with an amazingly life-like experience.  Students
will learn about all the technology that goes into the simulator and the range
of job fields available to them beyond pilot and crew that are  There’s a forecast shortage of new graduate
with the needed skills; the TriStar mission is important to the kid and to a
range of industries that support the aviation and aerospace industries.The Simulator SpaceHere are the initial construction drawings:We have already been working with the
design engineers, architects and construction firms that can complete our
