story:
Joan Koenig founded L’Ecole Koenig-The American Conservatory in 1986 with a total of 10 students. Today, L’Ecole Koenig American Conservatory & Kindergarten comprises 400 students and 300 families.

L’Ecole Koenig has never ceased developing and expanding its programs. Joan Koenig’s research and innovative work with music and early childhood, along with her talented teaching team, have earned the conservatory a solid reputation in the Parisian community.

Further fruit of this research, the Preschool for Music & Art opened its doors in 2008. The results of the program are exemplary both musically and linguistically. The Preschool for Music & Art, which became the Kindergarten in 2013, is so successful that a second campus was opened in the fall of 2013.

Our philosophy rests on certain key aspects:

Personal
Discipline

All the fine arts require personal discipline. Young children develop this naturally if they are carefully guided and encouraged.

Inspiration

High-level professional teaching is especially important at a very young age because children need to be inspired, even entranced.

Early-Childhood

Human beings are naturally musical, otherwise music would not exist. A child’s ear can and should be developed as early as possible. The benefits of early musical training will remain throughout his or her life.

High-level Musical
Education

Although the school has grown and diversified in the past quarter century, Joan Koenig and Betsy Schlesinger, Associate Director, have remained uncompromising about the mission of the school; maintaining the highest quality musical instruction in a warm and encouraging environment.

International
Perpectives

Today our staff of 26 musicians/teachers welcomes 400 students every year. Our music conservatory and our preschool / kindergarten are international not only because of their student body and staff, but also because of the international perspectives we offer to our students.

There are many children who are extremely talented and dedicated to music but unable to take lessons due to their family’s financial difficulties.  This fund provides opportunities for these children to have access to the extraordinary education that the Ecole Koenig provides.

story:
Short Summary

Positively Persistent Teach is a pillar of the Tumblr Education community. She is always there to support educators whether it's through giving advice, providing resources, or connecting other educators with one another. She's amazing, and it's likely that she's probably done something to personally help you. Now, she needs our help!

What We Need & What You Get

Recently, PPT has experienced a death in the family, and she needs to take a plane to get to the funeral. I researched how much round-trip air plane tickets are, and they are disgustingly expensive, especially if you are trying to buy them in the immediate future. I rounded the flights up to $900, most of it will be used for the airplane ticket, and the rest of the funds will be used for anything that needs to be bought for the funeral.

The Impact

By helping her out with this we show our support to an educator that has always shown nothing but heart and support back to use. Let's pay it forward.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any fund contributions will help. Also, please send this message out through reblogging or emailing.

story:
Our Campaign: WLP is a mentoring and leadership program for young women of color in South Los Angeles high schools. The program is staffed by educator-mentors Sikivu Hutchinson and Diane Arellano. The Secular Student Alliance (SSA) has generously offered us a matching fund grant of $1500:

"The Secular Student Alliance wants to support the Women's Leadership Project with a $1,500 matching offer.  This comes with no obligation on your part, other than to keep helping young women challenge the sexism, misogyny, and homophobia that can so powerfully shape their lives."

--SSA president August Brunsman


Our Story: Women's Leadership Project (WLP) fills a vacuum in a school district that has few programs that specifically address the intersection of sexism, racism, misogyny and heterosexism in the lives of young women of color. The program is designed to redress the normalized violence that young women of color encounter on a daily basis and has trained hundreds of 10-12th students to question and challenge the normalization of violence against women and advocate for safer school-communities. 

Our Project and Why it Matters: Using a feminist secular humanist curriculum, WLP trains young women of color high school students to do peer education outreach on violence prevention, reproductive justice, HIV/AIDS education, LGBTQ equality, undocumented youth advocacy and sexual assault awareness. The majority of our students are first generation (first in the family) college students and the WLP college prep curriculum sends girls of color to four year colleges and universities at above average rates. For example, the four-year college going rate at partner school Gardena High Schoool is approximately 20%.  WLP's four year rate is over 90%. WLP is the only program for girls of color that explicitly addresses the relationship between organized religion, sexism and misogyny and homophobia. The campaign will provide funding to keep this program sustainable with quality programming and mentorship. The past three WLP cohorts have received prestigious scholarships to top four year colleges and universities.  The majority of our participants are first generation college students. 2012-2013 cohorts have received full scholarships to private universities from the Posse Foundation and QuestBridge.

Why We Need Your Help:  Funding for WLP's program coordinator will expire this month.  For the past five years, the program has been funded through county government sources annually at $20,000 for the program coordinator's part-time salary of 25 hours a week. Our fundraising ask plus the matching grant will cover her salary for 2 months. All additional funds raised will contribute toward the program coordinator while we continue to seek additional funding for 2014. The program coordinator works on a daily basis with students at our three school sites.  The coordinator helps recruit students, develops lesson plans and gender justice curricula, trains students to do peer education workshops and works directly with first generation students on their college plans.

story:
REACH Program for Stroke Survivors

"… like having your own private earthquake."

REACH stands for Rehabilitation, Education, Acceptance, Community, and Hope. The REACH Program has been helping stroke survivors put their lives back together for 24 years. More than 2,400 students have been served by the Program. REACH was established in 1989 as part of Foothill College in Palo Alto to serve the needs of stroke survivors and others with acquired brain injuries. We provide serious help for adults who are recovering from these life-changing events. The program provides an essential link between outpatient rehabilitation and full reintegration into the community. 

Who is REACH For?  REACH is for people whose insurance has stopped paying, but their potential for improvement has not stopped. REACH classes are small group settings for sharing ideas, accomplishments, support, and encouragement with others who have had similar experiences. REACH classes are taught by instructors who are licensed experienced therapists in physical therapy, occupational therapy and speech and language therapy. The specific classes are

  • Mobility & Fitness Skills - Including gait training, mobility, balance and ambulation, muscle retraining, strengthening, and pain management. They help the student gain in stamina and endurance.
  • Adaptive Living Skills - Including perceptual and motor activities, upper extremity exercises and spasticity control. These make everyday tasks easier. 
  • Communication Skills - Including cognitive memory activities, motor speech production and pragmatics. Activities are tailored for each student's needs.

The REACH Program encourages individual independence,  so that each student can achieve his or her maximum physical, emotional and social potential.  REACH provides an environment that allows each person to accept their own limitations and develop a positive attitude toward themselves, their families and their communities.

Why Does REACH Need Help Now? REACH ran as part of Foothill College until the California state budget crunch cut our funding drastically in 2010 and again in 2012. With some support from the school, we became a stand-alone program, and filed for 501[c]3 tax-exempt status in November 2012. Tuitions were raised dramatically, we negotiated fair contracts with our loyal instructors and a rent-free lease on our building through 2015, and we are close to a self-sustaining, break even cash flow.

We need to raise a modest amount of capital to fund some essentials: tuition assistance for some of our students, add some additional classes and support staff, and allow us to make some needed repairs and maintenance on our equipment. If we raise enough, we will expand the  number of classes. We are currently serving about 70 students, but the number of folks surviving strokes continues to grow. 

REACH is also invaluable to the caregivers of our students. They get two days a week respite, when the students attend on either Monday/Wednesday or Tuesday/Thursday. If you've ever had caregiving responsibilities, you know what that means to them. 

Our executive director has been part of REACH since its founding, and she is very careful with every dime. She does the speech and communications classes, and she has hired the staff, most of whom have taught at REACH for more than ten years. 

In addition to our executive director, the REACH board of directors includes a doctor from Kaiser Permanente, a psychiatrist from Stanford, and two Silicon Valley executives. They all serve pro bono. 

Check out our picture gallery, and watch our video, which was created in 2011, the last year we were part of Foothill College. The REACH Program is rock solid, a proven program that has helped thousands of stroke survivors to get the most out of their lives. Please contribute what you can to help us continue this vital program. And spread the word - nearly everyone knows a family which has been touched by stroke.

Rehabilitation, Education, Acceptance, Community, and Hope - what REACH stands for. 

Thanks for your time and consideration, and happy holidays to you from the REACH team.

story:
Help Put the FIRE OUT!

Macio and LaWanda's home caught fire on Thursday, July 19th. They were enjoying dinner upstairs with some friends and minutes later they discovered thick black smoke accompanying the alarming smoke detectors. A few flashes later, around 20 firefighters stormed the home to put out the physical fire. Thank God they are safe, unharmed and their kids were safely visiting their grandmother during this traumatic experience. The physical fire is out but it has left a horrendous cloud of damage.

The walls of the home are covered in dark, oily, black soot. Their downstairs floor is completely ruined and much of their clothes and belongings, also ruined by the soot and smoke. They can't even sit on their couches because of the damaging soot. Their carpets are over run by it. The firefighters busted windows, belongings, and walls to ensure the fire was put out and save what could be saved.

Though, full of heart and strength, Macio and LaWanda need help. We are in some certainty that the insurance will cover the physical damage to the house but their belongings, clothes, their children's toys and furniture are forever damaged. We put this campaign on to bring a community together, near and far, to help a great family in need. 

Will you, please, help put the fire out in Macio and LaWanda's home and get them back what the fire took from them?

The Impact

They have lost a great amount and will be unable to use and live in their home for a substantial amount of time until insurance and contractors begin helping restore the house back to a liveable home.

Contributing to this need would do the following:

  • Housing (Hotel) for the time their house will be repaired.
  • Damage that the insurance will be unable to cover
  • Clothes to replace what was damaged for both Macio and LaWanda and their two wonderful children.
  • Furniture to replace the couches they are unable to sit on.
  • Belongings that were broke while the firefighters rushed through the home.

Everything counts and please help make a miracle real to them.

Other Ways You Can Help

We have setup other ways you can help:

  • First, obviously, you can give on this site.
  • You can also give to them directly (cash, check, items)
  • You can also use your credit card directly in person, just ask them how.
  • You can cook for them, buy groceries, love on them, pray for them.

Please ask LaWanda where you can send checks, items, etc if you can't give on this website. 

We thank you, we love you and please thank you for helping Macio and LaWanda put the fire out.

story:
Short Summary

We're a small organisation (we only employ 9 people) that has for the last 30+ years given well over 5000 young people an experience in the bush that they may well have helped to shape their lives. In particular, our belief is that getting away from your usual peer group, away from technology (we have no electricity) and experiencing something different are catalysts for change. 

We are based on a 400 acre stunning property and from here we hike up and camp in the mountains. Over winter we run alpine expeditions for those young people who may have never otherwise come in contact with the snow and extreme conditions. We supply all of the young people who visit with the gear they need, making skiing, a sport that is usually financially beyond reach for much of the population, accessible to all.

Our current supply of snow boots are wearing thin and without them we are unable to run programs in the snow. We need your help. Each pair of snow boot costs around $150 to purchase. We are hoping to get up to 30 pairs but need at least 20 to continue to run our programs.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We've been looking at snow boots to purchase and we can find pairs for $150 AUS that suit our programs.

For every $150 raised we will be able to purchase another pair of boots. We ultimately want to be able to purchase 20+ pairs of boots (this would mean we can run our programs at 80% capacity). For every $150 we go over, this means we can afford another pair. 

We would be happy to show any contributor the receipts for our purchase so you know that the money you give goes directly to where we say it's going to. 

 

The Impact

100% of young people who come on our programs get something from their experience. 66.67% of these people feel Mittagundi helped them to put things in perspective, gave them a love for the outdoors and an appreciation of nature.

"It's where kids get to be free and themselves for a few special days" (mother of a participant)

"It helps to grow their ability to communicate with others, building friendships and self esteem" (school teacher)

"You enable young people to be stronger in their own self, happy with who they are, experiencing something that they have never experienced, learn to trust others as well as finding out that hard work and committment can be fun." (mother of a participant)

"I've never spent a more memorable, challenging, emotional and, above all, fantastic 10 days." (One of our young program participants)

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell people about us. 

The more young people we can get through our doors then the better the world will be. We think young people have a lot to give and we want to support them on that road. Know someone aged 14-17 or know of people who work with young people? Send them our way.
story_txt:
Short Summary
We're a small organisation (we only employ 9 people) that has for the last 30+ years given well over 5000 young people an experience in the bush that they may well have helped to shape their lives. In particular, our belief is that getting away from your usual peer group, away from technology (we have no electricity) and experiencing something different are catalysts for change. 
We are based on a 400 acre stunning property and from here we hike up and camp in the mountains. Over winter we run alpine expeditions for those young people who may have never otherwise come in contact with the snow and extreme conditions. We supply all of the young people who visit with the gear they need, making skiing, a sport that is usually financially beyond reach for much of the population, accessible to all.
Our current supply of snow boots are wearing thin and without them we are unable to run programs in the snow. We need your help. Each pair of snow boot costs around $150 to purchase. We are hoping to get up to 30 pairs but need at least 20 to continue to run our programs.
 


What We Need & What You Get
We've been looking at snow boots to purchase and we can find pairs for $150 AUS that suit our programs.
For every $150 raised we will be able to purchase another pair of boots. We ultimately want to be able to purchase 20+ pairs of boots (this would mean we can run our programs at 80% capacity). For every $150 we go over, this means we can afford another pair. 
We would be happy to show any contributor the receipts for our purchase so you know that the money you give goes directly to where we say it's going to. 
 


The Impact
100% of young people who come on our programs get something from their experience. 66.67% of these people feel Mittagundi helped them to put things in perspective, gave them a love for the outdoors and an appreciation of nature.
"It's where kids get to be free and themselves for a few special days" (mother of a participant)
"It helps to grow their ability to communicate with others, building friendships and self esteem" (school teacher)
"You enable young people to be stronger in their own self, happy with who they are, experiencing something that they have never experienced, learn to trust others as well as finding out that hard work and committment can be fun." (mother of a participant)
"I've never spent a more memorable, challenging, emotional and, above all, fantastic 10 days." (One of our young program participants)

story:
**IMPORTANT Donation Update**

Please donate using the direct credit card method through Indiegogo rather than Paypal. Do not donate through Paypal - your donation will not be accepted. We're very sorry for any inconvenience, but we are having difficulty with Paypal, and it looks like our issue will not be resolved anytime soon. If you are unable to donate via the direct credit card option, please contact us at kyclub.info@gmail.com for other options.

What's Karuna Youth Club?

The Karuna Youth Club is a nonprofit organization that works on education projects with poor youths and children around Cambodia.

The Karuna Youth Club organization was founded in August 2011 by Mr. Kim Sav Phearith, a former youth in the Beoung Kok Lake slum area of Phnom Penh. Though it began empty-handed, KYC has engaged the community with humanitarian work by educating people about languages, leadership skills and morality, providing a place for poor students to live, and providing scholarships for poor children to learn and have a better life.

For the past 3 years, we have been helped more than 2,000 youths and children in Phnom Penh and various provinces.

What's Karuna Center for Education?

The Karuna Center for Education is a community school that we plan to build for poor children in the rural Aural district, Kompong Speu province. The school will provide free lessons in both national and foreign languages to many poor children and youths. Besides languages, the school will have professional teaching of other skills and short training courses, including morality, leadership and team work courses. In addition, this school will be a place for villagers to hold community meetings and trainings.

We estimate that, when we launch the school we will have more than 100 youths and children come to study here per day. We hope that this center will become an important resource contributing to improvement of education.

(Karuna Center for Education)

                                                                  (School Map Area)

                                                                     (Donor Wall)


Some background about the school community:

Trapoang Chor commune is approximately 120 km southwest of Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. It’s located in the rural area of Aural district, Kompong Speu province. Most of the people who live there are farmers whose work depends on nature. Some children there studied in primary school classes but drop out before or after finishing the secondary level because of the low quality of the school and the lack of any high school there. A small number of students who have completed secondary school here continue to study in the province town and the city. A large number of students who have completed their studying are working at a factory and sugar cane company. There are many poor people in the community with no water, no electricity and lack of education and health services.

Our goals:

• Build a school building of 15 m by 8 m

• Build a toilet

• Purchase a solar power system

• Build a water system and water tank

• Provide textbooks, writing utensils, and paper for all students

• Provide other school supplies

• Support community teachers

Why donate?

When you donate to this campaign, you will see how you're helping the school first-hand. We will update Indiegogo and our Facebook page with photos and news about the ongoing construction of the school. With your help and the tenacity of the Karuna Center for Education’s students, teachers and parents, a wonderful space for learning will continue to grow.

We greatly appreciate any donation amount, and you will receive some awesome perks as a thank you at each level:

$5 donation: We will put your name on our Facebook page.

$10 donation: We will put your name on our website and Facebook page. This amount funds English class for three days for over 100 children.

$15 donation: You will receive a personal thank email from our team and we will put your name on our website and Facebook page. This amount funds school supplies for 15 days. 

$30 donation: We will email you a picture of one of our students holding a sign with your name, plus all of the perks already mentioned above. This amount funds school supplies for a month.

$50 donation: You will receive a one-minute thank you video from our team or students, plus all of the perks already mentioned above. This amount funds 2 percent of the building construction costs.

$100 donation: Your name will be put on Karuna Center for Education’s virtual donor wall, plus all of the perks above. This amount supports a local community teacher (with over 100 students) for a month.

$300 donation: We will schedule a Skype call for you with our team and our students. You will also get a chance to visit our Phnom Penh facility if you are in Cambodia, plus all of the perks above. This amount funds the purchase of a toilet and a water tank for over 100 students.

$500+ donation: You will be recognized as a Major Donor, and if you are in Cambodia, you will get a trip to visit our school and community in Aural for two days (we will provide local transportation, accommodation and food). You will also receive all of the perks above. This amount funds 12.5 percent of the building construction costs.

Unable to donate but still want to help?

Please use the Indiegogo “share” features on this page or spread the word yourself on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/karunayouthclub. Also, please email this campaign to your family and friends. For any questions, please send a message through Indiegogo or email kyclub.info@gmail.com

A little about us

Fundraising for Karuna Center for Education is administred by the Karuna Youth Club team members who are willing to help make this community school possible. Please find more information about us at https://www.facebook.com/karunayouthclub or www.kyc-cambodia.org.

story:
Our Story

The Alliance for Career and Education Inc. (ACE) is a Maryland non-profit organization specializing in providing Student Transition and Entry Preparation (STEPï¿½) for positive youth development. ACE encourages young people to STEPï¿½ up to their future, by offering research-based educational enrichment courses focused on mastering the skills necessary to be successful in life. In addition to college planning and preparation, ACE provides valuable pre-career training, internships, and job placement for students wishing to enter the workforce. ACE also provides focused content college and career planning for students who would like to pursue athletics, or work in the arts or entertainment industries.


Due to our location in Baltimore, ACE has the unique opportunity to work in neighborhoods with high dropout rates, and to encourage at-risk youth to STEPï¿½ up to their future and stay on the path to success. The goal of this campaign is to raise additional funds so that we can continue to provide these critical services for young people in Maryland.


The Impact

Across the nation, 31% of ninth-graders do not graduate high school with a diploma within four years. The plight is even more drastic in urban areas, and in Baltimore City the number of students who do not make it to graduation is nearly twice the national average. The problem is exacerbated by the fact that school programs often lack the tools to reach students who are struggling with the inspiration and motivation necessary to successfully plan for the future.


By providing Student Transition and Entry Programs, as well as using constructive interests like athletics and the performing arts, ACE strives to motivate and inspire young people to plan and prepare for the future. Motivational seminars and personal coaching provide youth with the guidance and inspiration they need, while transition readiness programs provide students with tools for success in the real world.


ACE has already begun to make a difference in our community, providing preparation and readiness services to Maryland students. ACE has conducted middle and high school programs at Paul's Place, a community center focused on providing services to low-income and homeless families in Southwest Baltimore. ACE also works closely in conjunction with former Harlem Globetrotter Choo Smith and Choo Smith Youth Empowerment, providing academic programs and college and career preparation for student-athletes.


What We Need & What You Get

All funds raised by the campaign will be used to provide ACE services to middle and high school students in the state of Maryland. Your contribution will give our organization the wings to soar, and to expand the reach of our program to more children in need.


Due to ACE's status as a Maryland 501(c)(3) non-profit corporation, all donations are tax deductible.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can give money. Times are tough! Please help us by spreading the word about the Alliance For Career and Education to your family, friends, and social networks.

story:
Why I need your support

According to the World Economic Forum, Peru's education system was ranked last in math and science scores and second to last in overall quality of education (2007). The Light and Leadership Initiative (LLI) supports Huaycan, a shantytown located outside of Lima, to reinforce learning in Huaycan's schools.

Huaycan is comprised of approximately 180,000 inhabitants, almost all of which live below the poverty line. 

LLI Mission:

The Light and Leadership Initiative's mission is to respond to the needs of the women in the Ate-Vitarte district of Huaycan, Peru in their struggle out of poverty by increasing the availability and quality of education offered to women and children. Through workshops and classes, women are empowered to better care for themselves and their families by improving both their physical and emotional well being, as well as advancing their skills in the workforce. Children are offered similar opportunities and learn the value of education and respect for one's community. We believe the women and children of the Ate-Vitarte district will become positive leaders for change through love, support, and education.

Your support will support volunteers and the program to facilitate this change.

About me and my work

I am a senior graduating from the University of Texas, May 2015, with a B.S. in Chemical Engineering. I volunteered in a mountain village in Oaxaca, Mexico the summer of my junior year in high school and taught after-school P.E. and nutrition classes. That trip showed me the power of cross-cultural exchange - from volunteer to community and the community on the volunteer.

I am volunteering with LLI because I believe in their mission. During my time in Peru this summer, I will be making lesson plans and leading art classes 4-5 days a week! I will also teach english classes. Aside from classes, I will be living in the community so that I can optimize my time with the children and begin to understand the lifestyle of my surrounding community. 

Photos from Oaxaca: (top left) 4 of my students - they loved playing with the camera and being in the spotlight, (top left) my get-well card when the flu kept me from class, (bottom) The class showing off their work on the last day.

Your contributions

Your donation will help fund my program fee, including housing. Your contribution indirectly supports other staff and volunteers that plan math, computer programming, english, art, physical education classes (and more!) that promote active learning and mental and physical health!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this with your friends! Read about LLI and learn about the program

  • Don't have the means to donate financially?  I’d love to read an encouraging word - leave messages in the top comments section :)

Thank you for taking the time to check out LLI and my page,

Sarah

story:
THE IMPOSSIBLE CITY is a Sawhorse Revolution program series that engages youth in building (and often designing) needed structures for Seattle's homeless encampments. As with all Sawhorse Revolution projects, the builds are guided by professionals in their fields - architecture, engineering, and construction. Sawhorse is a registered 501 (c)3 not-for-profit organization. 

 

Each project is tailored to the needs of the camp and crafted to be of the highest quality, incorporating sustainable materials and building techniques, beautiful design, and a user-centered approach to architecture. Since the LIHI / Nickelsville Homeless Communities we work with move every 3-18 months, every structure we build is easily transportable and designed to fit the needs of homeless residents in transition to permanent housing.

 

We've already built seven amazing structures thanks to a successful Indiegogo campaign last year, and we're hoping you'll help us create four more by donating now to the Impossible City. 
 

HELP US BUILD!

Here are the projects we're working on next:
 

"The Parabay Homes," a tiny house "duplex" that can house a family


Concept: After working with the villages, we discovered that many of the families who arrive at the camps are too large to fit in one, 120 square-foot tiny house. Last summer, a design team came up with the Parabay Homes, designed to enable easy communication and connection between family members in each space.
Status: Design complete, construction has begun, funds needed to finish construction

Security Booth, essential safety infrastructure

Concept: The encampments that Sawhorse works with have 24 hour security, staffed by camp residents themselves. As the entrance to the village and the hub of many of its functions, a well-designed booth would greatly improve residents' lives.
Status: Design complete; build scheduled with the all-women's program for spring 2017
 

Tiny House #9

Concept: The continued gift of considerately-designed, eco-friendly passive homes is an ongoing need for people experiencing homeless in Seattle. This new tiny house will prototype murphy bed construction and other moving canopy parts that can expand living area without violating city codes.
Status: Design Scheduled for Jan 2017, Build Scheduled to begin March 2017
 

WHO ARE WE BUILDING FOR? 

In brief, we work with a formal, independent, non-profit backed homeless encampment group  - Nickelsville. Nickelsville comprises of a network of encampments in the Seattle area, all sitting on city-sanctioned land. Nickelsville camps are self-governed, meaning residents each put in work to maintaining, governing, and securing these small villages. Nickelsvilles are also entirely substance-free, with strict regulations around inebriation and behavior. Some are full tiny house villages, some include mostly tents, and some comprise a mix of the two.

Encampments are seen as an emergency, transitional homeless housing measure that has many benefits for residents. Safe storage, 24 hour security, coordinated meals, access to services, and, most importantly, a community, are often essential for people working to get themselves back on their feet. More than half of residents work during the day, but Seattle's housing boom has raised rents for everyone; statistics show that for every $100/month rents go up, homelessness rises by 15%. 

Since 2015, Seattle has sanctioned six of these camps to act as transitional housing for people experiencing homelessness. The camps work in conjunction with the Low Income Housing Institute. Families who can't find affordable apartments in Seattle's booming economy frequently take refuge in one of the villages as they wait for housing to open up. Our houses and beyond go to these camps. 
 

WHAT WE'VE DONE SO FAR

Last year, Indiegogo supporters helped us build seven new structures for the Nickelsville Homeless Community, and we're very proud to show the beautiful results of everybody's work!
 

Bathrooms

Concept: The first project Nickelsville requested that we build were bathrooms. This simple, double-stall structure has two bathrooms, including one wheelchair accessible bathroom. Now fully plumbed in, the bathroom includes sinks on both sides with heated water.
Status: Installed in Central District Tiny House Village January 2016

Hinge House


Concept: That the tiny house villages are temporary means that each structure has to move; loading the houses on a truck constrains the height, and, therefore, the space available for a lofted bed. One design team decided to solve this by creating a house with a hinged roof. During transport, the roof can be lowered. Once the house is in place, the roof lifts, creating ample loft bed space in the interior!
Status: Built fall 2016


Salvage House

Concept: True to our original concept of building an eco-village, we designed this house to incorporate 80%+ salvaged materials. It incorporates a beautiful sheltered porch, storage outside and inside, and a loft bed with a desk on the interior as well. This tiny house represents the results from feedback from all previous tiny houses about loft beds, storage, a porch, and salvaged materials. Residents at a local homeless village refer to it as the "cadillac" of tiny houses.
Status: Completed spring 2016, installed at South Seattle Tiny House Village

 

EASE.L House

Concept: Designed and built by our all-women's program, the EASE.L House takes into consideration residents' desire to shape their own spaces. High windows and high r-value insulation make a warm, cozy, and private space, while custom designed and built furniture is flexible enough for a family of 4 or a single occupant. One interior wall is entirely cork while the other is all chalkboard. Thus, the theme of a house that offers privacy, flexibility, and ample opportunity for self-expression comes to life!
Status: Completed summer 2016, will be installed soon at a tiny house village. 

 

Wheelchair Ramp

Concept: Where there was once just a set of ad-hoc stairs leading to the ADA-accommodating bathrooms in the Central District tiny house village, now there's a deluxe, cedar and engineered decking ramp in place, per the request of the Nickelsville camp!
Status: Built spring 2016, installed at Central District Tiny House Village

A-Frames 1 + 2

Concept: Originally designed to be one large tiny house built on a module, we split the original A-Frame into two to create two identical and adorable tiny homes. These tiny but functional houses allow residents ample sleeping and storage space. A passive housing design and build approach maximizes interior space while allowing the warmest possible, eco-friendly house for a resident!
Status: Build in process, will be completed early December 2016

 

IMPACT

We started Sawhorse Revolution's construction projects for the homeless in early 2014, and have maintained our commitment to engage youth in creating considerately-designed structures as needed, and as requested, by the camps. Since beginning this program, our impact has been both strong and unique!

A New Model for Education and Community Service
For each home or other project built, 6-24 youth develop basic skills in carpentry, design, and more. They work with peers and mentors, and the homes become almost a story of education and learning; each successfully installed piece of wood acts as a journal of sorts, recording our students' perseverance in learning new skills, creative ideas for storage and dignity, and collaboration with peers and mentors. 

Crucial Shelter for Families in Need
Seattle’s homeless population is growing at an astonishing rate, and one of the measures the city has taken is to sanction legal, self-governed, substance-free encampments. Those we work with often have tiny houses and provide emergency housing for families waiting for transitional housing.  

Cost-effective housing model
Though we’re not trying to solve homelessness with this model, we are hoping to show how small groups can come together with limited resources and create something amazing that makes a real difference. If more groups could take our model and run with it, imagine the possibilities for youth and homelessness around the country.

 

BUDGET

Our projects achieve a low materials cost while incorporating high quality materials (see above: design is dignity) thanks to donations from generous companies who produce and sell high-performance building products. Still, purchased materials are always essential, and this is where you come in. 

We've included specific budgets for each of the projects in the links below, but you can also reference the following quick budget summaries!
 

Family Duplex (Two Homes)
Funds needed from Indiegogo: $7,780
Materials: $3,300/house ($6,600 total)
Moving: $1180

Security Office
Funds needed from Indiegogo: $5,590
Materials: $5,500
Moving: $590

New Tiny Home:
Total requested from Indiegogo: $5,090
Materials: $4,500
Moving: $590


PERKS!
$10 - Stickers:

$25 - Patch

$35 - Revolutionary Bandana

$50 - Dream, Design, Build T-Shirt

$50 - Work Party T-Shirt

 

$75 - Beanie

$75 - T-Shirt and Bandana

$99 - T-Shirt and Beanie

$125 - Signed Photo of a Tiny House



$250 - Tiny House Framing Plan Poster


$500 - Laser-Etched Hammer

 

$750 - All of the Above


$1,000 - All of the Above, in a Toolbox!


$2,500 - All of the above, plus a Tour


$5,000 - Fund a house <3


With this gift, we'll send you all of the gifts from above, but you'll have the added knowledge that you've contributed to shelter and youth empowerment. The gratitude of so many people comes your way!

Additional Footage: Stacey Jenkins and KCTS 9, Elliott Trotter, Dom Campese

story_txt:
THE IMPOSSIBLE CITY is a Sawhorse Revolution program series that engages youth in building (and often designing) needed structures for Seattle's homeless encampments. As with all Sawhorse Revolution projects, the builds are guided by professionals in their fields - architecture, engineering, and construction. Sawhorse is a registered 501 (c)3 not-for-profit organization. 

 
Each project is tailored to the needs of the camp and crafted to be of the highest quality, incorporating sustainable materials and building techniques, beautiful design, and a user-centered approach to architecture. Since the LIHI / Nickelsville Homeless Communities we work with move every 3-18 months, every structure we build is easily transportable and designed to fit the needs of homeless residents in transition to permanent housing.
 

We've already built seven amazing structures thanks to a successful Indiegogo campaign last year, and we're hoping you'll help us create four more by donating now to the Impossible City.  
HELP US BUILD!
Here are the projects we're working on next: 
"The Parabay Homes," a tiny house "duplex" that can house a family
Concept: After working with the villages, we discovered that many of the families who arrive at the camps are too large to fit in one, 120 square-foot tiny house. Last summer, a design team came up with the Parabay Homes, designed to enable easy communication and connection between family members in each space.Status: Design complete, construction has begun, funds needed to finish constructionSecurity Booth, essential safety infrastructure

Concept: The encampments that Sawhorse works with have 24 hour security, staffed by camp residents themselves. As the entrance to the village and the hub of many of its functions, a well-designed booth would greatly improve residents' lives.Status: Design complete; build scheduled with the all-women's program for spring 2017 
Tiny House #9
Concept: The continued gift of considerately-designed, eco-friendly passive homes is an ongoing need for people experiencing homeless in Seattle. This new tiny house will prototype murphy bed construction and other moving canopy parts that can expand living area without violating city codes.Status: Design Scheduled for Jan 2017, Build Scheduled to begin March 2017 

WHO ARE WE BUILDING FOR? 
In brief, we work with a formal, independent, non-profit backed homeless encampment group  - Nickelsville. Nickelsville comprises of a network of encampments in the Seattle area, all sitting on city-sanctioned land. Nickelsville camps are self-governed, meaning residents each put in work to maintaining, governing, and securing these small villages. Nickelsvilles are also entirely substance-free, with strict regulations around inebriation and behavior. Some are full tiny house villages, some include mostly tents, and some comprise a mix of the two.
Encampments are seen as an emergency, transitional homeless housing measure that has many benefits for residents. Safe storage, 24 hour security, coordinated meals, access to services, and, most importantly, a community, are often essential for people working to get themselves back on their feet. More than half of residents work during the day, but Seattle's housing boom has raised rents for everyone; statistics show that for every $100/month rents go up, homelessness rises by 15%. Since 2015, Seattle has sanctioned six of these camps to act as transitional housing for people experiencing homelessness. The camps work in conjunction with the Low Income Housing Institute. Families who can't find affordable apartments in Seattle's booming economy frequently take refuge in one of the villages as they wait for housing to open up. Our houses and beyond go to these camps.  
WHAT WE'VE DONE SO FAR
Last year, Indiegogo supporters helped us build seven new structures for the Nickelsville Homeless Community, and we're very proud to show the beautiful results of everybody's work! 
Bathrooms

Concept: The first project Nickelsville requested that we build were bathrooms. This simple, double-stall structure has two bathrooms, including one wheelchair accessible bathroom. Now fully plumbed in, the bathroom includes sinks on both sides with heated water.Status: Installed in Central District Tiny House Village January 2016
Hinge House

Concept: That the tiny house villages are temporary means that each structure has to move; loading the houses on a truck constrains the height, and, therefore, the space available for a lofted bed. One design team decided to solve this by creating a house with a hinged roof. During transport, the roof can be lowered. Once the house is in place, the roof lifts, creating ample loft bed space in the interior!Status: Built fall 2016
Salvage HouseConcept: True to our original concept of building an eco-village, we designed this house to incorporate 80%+ salvaged materials. It incorporates a beautiful sheltered porch, storage outside and inside, and a loft bed with a desk on the interior as well. This tiny house represents the results from feedback from all previous tiny houses about loft beds, storage, a porch, and salvaged materials. Residents at a local homeless village refer to it as the "cadillac" of tiny houses.Status: Completed spring 2016, installed at South Seattle Tiny House Village
 
EASE.L HouseConcept: Designed and built by our all-women's program, the EASE.L House takes into consideration residents' desire to shape their own spaces. High windows and high r-value insulation make a warm, cozy, and private space, while custom designed and built furniture is flexible enough for a family of 4 or a single occupant. One interior wall is entirely cork while the other is all chalkboard. Thus, the theme of a house that offers privacy, flexibility, and ample opportunity for self-expression comes to life!Status: Completed summer 2016, will be installed soon at a tiny house village. 
 
Wheelchair RampConcept: Where there was once just a set of ad-hoc stairs leading to the ADA-accommodating bathrooms in the Central District tiny house village, now there's a deluxe, cedar and engineered decking ramp in place, per the request of the Nickelsville camp!Status: Built spring 2016, installed at Central District Tiny House VillageA-Frames 1 + 2Concept: Originally designed to be one large tiny house built on a module, we split the original A-Frame into two to create two identical and adorable tiny homes. These tiny but functional houses allow residents ample sleeping and storage space. A passive housing design and build approach maximizes interior space while allowing the warmest possible, eco-friendly house for a resident!Status: Build in process, will be completed early December 2016
 
IMPACT
We started Sawhorse Revolution's construction projects for the homeless in early 2014, and have maintained our commitment to engage youth in creating considerately-designed structures as needed, and as requested, by the camps. Since beginning this program, our impact has been both strong and unique!A New Model for Education and Community ServiceFor each home or other project built, 6-24 youth develop basic skills in carpentry, design, and more. They work with peers and mentors, and the homes become almost a story of education and learning; each successfully installed piece of wood acts as a journal of sorts, recording our students' perseverance in learning new skills, creative ideas for storage and dignity, and collaboration with peers and mentors. 
Crucial Shelter for Families in NeedSeattle’s homeless population is growing at an astonishing rate, and one of the measures the city has taken is to sanction legal, self-governed, substance-free encampments. Those we work with often have tiny houses and provide emergency housing for families waiting for transitional housing.  Cost-effective housing modelThough we’re not trying to solve homelessness with this model, we are hoping to show how small groups can come together with limited resources and create something amazing that makes a real difference. If more groups could take our model and run with it, imagine the possibilities for youth and homelessness around the country.
 
BUDGET
Our projects achieve a low materials cost while incorporating high quality materials (see above: design is dignity) thanks to donations from generous companies who produce and sell high-performance building products. Still, purchased materials are always essential, and this is where you come in. 
We've included specific budgets for each of the projects in the links below, but you can also reference the following quick budget summaries! 
Family Duplex (Two Homes)Funds needed from Indiegogo: $7,780Materials: $3,300/house ($6,600 total)Moving: $1180Security OfficeFunds needed from Indiegogo: $5,590Materials: $5,500Moving: $590New Tiny Home:Total requested from Indiegogo: $5,090Materials: $4,500Moving: $590

$5,000 - Fund a house <3
With this gift, we'll send you all of the gifts from above, but you'll have the added knowledge that you've contributed to shelter and youth empowerment. The gratitude of so many people comes your way!

story:
One World Youth Project
http://oneworldyouthproject.org

Hello! Two outstanding students from the National University of Sciences and Technology (NUST) in Islamabad, Pakistan have been selected as the first ever university student leaders (or Project Manager Fellows) for the One World Youth Project (OWYP) program in Pakistan. OWYP links schools across the world to create mutual respect and understanding among students. The two Project Manager Fellows manage the "Hub" on the NUST campus, which is comprised of their peers who facilitate cross-cultural exchanges between local Pakistani secondary school students and their peers abroad in countries like the USA, Turkey, Kosovo and Guyana.

In order to successfully lead this program in Pakistan, the Project Manager Fellows must attend a training in Kosovo to gain the essential skills in leadership, management, cross-cultural communication, and most importantly, to build a cohesive international community with their peers.

It promises to be an incredible trip for the NUST Project Manager Fellows to interact with similarly ambitious students who are seeking new ways to connect and collaborate with peers beyond national borders. The trip will allow Project Manager Fellows to develop leadership and management skills, learn about their peers' countries and cultures and prepare them for the upcoming service-learning work they will have in their communities. For most students in attendance, it will be their first opportunity abroad in a place that is so culturally different than where they are living.

Please help us empower local Pakistani youth to connect with others globally and make positive change within their local community!

What is the Summer Training Conference?

The Summer Training Conference (STC) is a weeklong experience where the Project Manager Fellows from OWYP Hub campuses worldwide come together to further develop their management, leadership and community-building skills.

This is a unique opportunity for OWYP's international leaders to come together as a team to learn from one another and form strong bonds across borders. The STC adequately prepares students to collaborate remotely with their partner secondary schools and universities abroad.

Check out this video from last year’s STC: http://youtu.be/vILw552FNFs

What is One World Youth Project?

One World Youth Project (OWYP) partners with universities and university students to build mutual respect and understanding among youth. Through the OWYP program, university students are trained to facilitate cross-cultural exchanges between local middle schools and middle schools abroad via technology. (Mentored by the university student facilitators, students gain empathetic and critical thinking skills that allow them to address challenges in their own communities with a newly developed global lens.)

The vision of OWYP is a just world built through the actions of empowered, discerning and empathetic generations of global citizens. For more information visit our website: http://www.oneworldyouthproject.org

Media

Pakistan Today: http://bit.ly/K3FTfs
The Nation: http://bit.ly/xgy6br

story:
Dancing has been my passion since I was 8. I completely fell in love with the art form while watching my nan shine in a tap class my mum and I happened to be picking her up from. I was enchanted. I wanted to feel as timeless as she looked.

However, my lessons have never been easy to afford. At 12 my mum was unable to keep paying for weekly training, so I started attending a street dance after school club run by my friend's mum. This saw me through a few years, and at 18 I got a part time job, allowing me to return, at 20,  to classical training in ballet, jazz, and street dance. These last two years have changed my life, making my dream of attending dance school more of a reality than ever before, and this year I am applying to professional schools in NY and the surrounding areas.

I do not expect to raise the money required to pay course fees and maintenance costs of attending school, as I fully appreciate there are other people on this site with important issues who need help, but I have high hopes that I will be able to raise to pay for dancing school in NY.


Dance is such a massive part of my life, and it would mean more than I can describe if I was able to study my dream subject for the next 3 years. 
Please help me overcome the painful trend that only those that are born with money can attend dance school.

Auditions start in the Winter of this year, so any contribution will be so gratefully received, even if it's just the 1$ you find under the sofa! 

Thank you in advance for making a little girls dream come true! All my love and gratitude, Makasha.

story:
Paying for graduate school isn't easy. Tuition, living expenses and supplies for a master's degree from the LBJ School of Public Affairs have eaten away my savings, forced me to sell belongings and take on odd jobs on campus whenever possible. I'm down to my last handful of credits, but my savings are tapped, scholarships are few, and as an international student, I can't get a loan. I'm close to finishing, and need just one last push to get over. Can you help me grab hold of a graduate degree in global policy and move on to change the world?

Global Citizens Don't Get FAFSA

I need to raise about $12,000 to cover a final semester's worth of tuition and the living expenses needed. Half will go to cover the final semester's tuition and the rest toward getting books, paying my rent and paying for necessitites like food and utilities. I've cut my other expenditures to the bone.

My family has been with me every step of the way, but financially exhausted by having to put my three younger brothers through school and chip in to support family affected by the earthquake. They've had to scrape into savings to cover unexpected costs. It's rough back home, and you can understand I'd like to keep from adding to their burdens.

I'm still in the process of looking for additional opportunities like paid internships and on campus employment. I'm hoping that by the end of this campaign (which is set to expire on the 28th of July, my birthday) I'll have enough lined up to give myself some additional breathing room in addition to what I can raise here.

Why this degree and Why Now?

In an increasingly globalized world, we need leaders who understand the issues facing everyone. A degree in global policy studies provides both the analytical skills and the necessary cachette to make a difference in the greater world. I'm in the process of embarking on my long-term career. A graduate degree would give me a head start in bringing smart, effective policies to the global arena. I need your help.

This also comes at a time when I've started blogging about global issues facing the world. I'd like to have the opportunity to use the degree to help open doors that can help me raise awareness of global policy issues to a wider audience. It's too important to let esoteric language and jargon crowd out the real concerns.

The budget cuts at the University of Texas have made it hard to find opportunities that are able to sufficiently support my needs. It's unfortunate that my TAship with the great kids around me in the photo above wasn't renewed last year, but hopefully y'all can help.

Making Global Issues More Understandable

In addition to my studies, I've also tried to translate what I've learned into a format that can be digested without the fancy policy learning. I'm firmly committed to the idea that policy analysts need to better communicate their ideas with the public.

As a contributor at the League of Ordinary Gentlemen,I blog about international affairs issues and associated policy, lending my expertise in a tangible way.

A sampling of my work can be found at this link.

My more interesting posts include:

  • Can States be Moral? The Curious Case of British Abolitionists

  • A Primer on the Trans-Pacific Partnership

     

How else can you help?

Spread the word! If you can't make a donation yourself, send the link along to others who might be able to help.

 

((Photo above is me in the red shirt, with a Japanese language class that I TAed last spring))

story:
Equalize Youth aims to become the world's support network for LGBTQ youth. We are a team of passionate young adults inspired by the impact of web-based initiatives like the It Gets Better Project and AllOut. Our project started from the heart and has developed with an eye on the safety, needs and behaviors of young LGBTQ people growing up in the world of iPhones, Facebook, Twitter, Google Maps, and many other social media platforms. 

Our site will make it easy for every adult make a difference in the lives of LGBTQ youth. LGBTQ adults, friends, and family will get to share their hope and wisdom, without compromising anyone's safety or privacy.  Adult contributors will out their stories and give young people like them hope and advice by sharing multimedia content themed around the unique things experiences of their own life path as LGBTQ folks.These will be stories of struggle, of success, of people simply being themselves. Real-life knowdlege on coming out, bullies, feeling ashamed, communicating with parents, handling crushes, being open in the workplace... Everyone gets to contribute, everywhere in the world.

There is a world of support out here, and we want to make it accessible for young people by harnessing the power of the technologies of our time.Help us to safely connect LGBTQ youth to the stories of people that have walked in their shoes: folks from their own town, school, ethnicity, or faith. We want create a genuine and safe place of hope and power generated by everyone who cares about the future of our communities.

If you can already hear the commotion... We invite you to visit this powerful and award winning resource. We want to provide something similar for LGBTQ youth everywhere. A place to insipire, and to be inspired. A place that gives youth the tools to move forward! This is Queerty's take on this project: 

"Equalize Youth is the next logical step after the It Gets Better Campaign" - Queerty, Sept 29th

Together we can make this worldwide tool a reality!

Our platform innovates by bringing location markers and background tags into the user experience, and by keeping contributors anonymous. We want to use this new social media approach to safely connect youth with the stories and experiences that were part of those that have walked in their shoes before. With a savvy Google Maps application, contributors tie entries to physical locations and important places related to their story: high schools, congregations, summer camps, and community centers—anywhere around the globe counts!

Searches will be as simple as entering a zip code. Kids can find entries by folks just like them, whether in their own hometowns or around the globe. Contributors will tag their ethnic backgrounds and religious upbringings in their entry to facilitate effective searches. Additional tags for experiences like being deaf, blind, going through “anti-gay therapy,” or being HIV+ will also be included. No matter what, we want youth to see (literally!) that they are not alone, that their challenges can be overcome, and that there is a world of unconditional love and support out there.

Let's be clear: we are serious about being a resource to all LGBTQ youth!

Equalize Youth will be a safe and readily available source of hope and power, put forth by real-life people that youth can relate to. It will be like nothing else out there, and available worldwide—a place to inspire and to be inspired, and give youth the tools that can help them move forward into healthier, more resilient, and optimistic lives.

The end result?

Generations of young LGBTQ teens people won't feel ashamed and ostracized. Kids will understand that the hostility they may face is not their fault, and that it stems from ignorance 100% unrelated to themselves, their value, their perfect selves. These youth will gain crucial access and connection to people that have faced the same challenges. They'll get to know how someone just like them has gone through it before—not only that these people exist, but also how they felt, where they are now, and how things are changing across the globe.  

Where will my money go?

Our current platform can accept written entries, but can't yet perform searches or organize results… It’s like a stand-in: it’s missing the meat—and a lot of it. We've gotten this far with the help of lawyers, software companies, designers, web developers, photographers, media consultants, bloggers, local nonprofits, and more. But we can't grow further without funding: skilled developers cost over $100/hour! We need your help!

Your money will go towards the development of the back-end “machine” we need to support our platform. It will organize the data, enable searches, and expand functionality. Your resources will enable the infrastructure necessary for this platform to exist. These resources will contribute to:

  • User Interface Design (it needs to look crazy good!)
  • Back-End Development (its a unique and complex platform. We need help!)
  • Custom Server Configuration (let's make it fast, shall we?)
  • Grassroots and Creative Outreach (getting the word out is key!)

By helping us to build this online interface, you'll help LGBTQ Youth access content they can relate to in a meaningful and personal way. To see themselves in stories will give them hope; knowing how others faced their own challenges will make them more resilient. They’ll get to know they are not alone, no matter where they are.

 

The contributor perks

We reward contributors with unique and limited run perks that our team will make, cook and craft, and they will always remind you of the important role you played in making this resource a reality. Click below and visit our gallery for images! 

We believe these to be superb perks, and there's something you should know about them: even though quite awesome, they fall (VERY) short of letting you know the full extent of our gratitude. A team bear hug would be a good start towards letting you know how thankful we are to have you onboard.

Stop for a second, and think of how sites like Google Maps, craigslist and reddit have truly changed how we live, think, and act. There is true potential for scalable, sustainable, and powerful change here. Every contribution helps us get closer to making it a tangible reality. Together, we can take it beyond our wildest dreams.

 If you believe that this platform will make a positive impact in the world, please show your support with even just a buck! Reading off those sixteen digits always go by faster than you expect :)

There are many ways to help - SHARING IS CARING!

We want to get info on this campaign to everyone cares: help us by sharing this page with friends, parents, your employer's LGBTQ group, your local LGBTQ center, your college campus' student-run organization—every little bit helps!

There are many other important ways in which you can make a powerful contribution and help us make it happen. Every sharing effort and donation matter a whole lot. We urge you to take a minute and:

  • Comment on our campaign page here.
  • Like and share our campaign and use indiegogo’s sharing tools. Share it with anyone with a heart! They don’t have to be gay, they just have to be human! Every single dollar, like, comment, and share counts.
  • Post our campaign page in Facebook Pages that you Like and are related to the LGBTQ movement
  • Like our Facebook Page

 

 

[ HERE'S THE BUZZ! CHECK OUT ALSO OTHER UPDATES AS WELL! ]
story_txt:
Equalize Youth aims to become the world's support network for LGBTQ youth. We are a team of passionate young adults inspired by the impact of web-based initiatives like the It Gets Better Project and AllOut. Our project started from the heart and has developed with an eye on the safety, needs and behaviors of young LGBTQ people growing up in the world of iPhones, Facebook, Twitter, Google Maps, and many other social media platforms. 
Our site will make it easy for every adult make a difference in the lives of LGBTQ youth. LGBTQ adults, friends, and family will get to share their hope and wisdom, without compromising anyone's safety or privacy.  Adult contributors will out their stories and give young people like them hope and advice by sharing multimedia content themed around the unique things experiences of their own life path as LGBTQ folks.These will be stories of struggle, of success, of people simply being themselves. Real-life knowdlege on coming out, bullies, feeling ashamed, communicating with parents, handling crushes, being open in the workplace... Everyone gets to contribute, everywhere in the world.
There is a world of support out here, and we want to make it accessible for young people by harnessing the power of the technologies of our time.Help us to safely connect LGBTQ youth to the stories of people that have walked in their shoes: folks from their own town, school, ethnicity, or faith. We want create a genuine and safe place of hope and power generated by everyone who cares about the future of our communities.
If you can already hear the commotion... We invite you to visit this powerful and award winning resource. We want to provide something similar for LGBTQ youth everywhere. A place to insipire, and to be inspired. A place that gives youth the tools to move forward! This is Queerty's take on this project: 
"Equalize Youth is the next logical step after the It Gets Better Campaign" - Queerty, Sept 29th


Together we can make this worldwide tool a reality!

Our platform innovates by bringing location markers and background tags into the user experience, and by keeping contributors anonymous. We want to use this new social media approach to safely connect youth with the stories and experiences that were part of those that have walked in their shoes before. With a savvy Google Maps application, contributors tie entries to physical locations and important places related to their story: high schools, congregations, summer camps, and community centers—anywhere around the globe counts!
Searches will be as simple as entering a zip code. Kids can find entries by folks just like them, whether in their own hometowns or around the globe. Contributors will tag their ethnic backgrounds and religious upbringings in their entry to facilitate effective searches. Additional tags for experiences like being deaf, blind, going through “anti-gay therapy,” or being HIV+ will also be included. No matter what, we want youth to see (literally!) that they are not alone, that their challenges can be overcome, and that there is a world of unconditional love and support out there.
Let's be clear: we are serious about being a resource to all LGBTQ youth!
Equalize Youth will be a safe and readily available source of hope and power, put forth by real-life people that youth can relate to. It will be like nothing else out there, and available worldwide—a place to inspire and to be inspired, and give youth the tools that can help them move forward into healthier, more resilient, and optimistic lives.
The end result?
Generations of young LGBTQ teens people won't feel ashamed and ostracized. Kids will understand that the hostility they may face is not their fault, and that it stems from ignorance 100% unrelated to themselves, their value, their perfect selves. These youth will gain crucial access and connection to people that have faced the same challenges. They'll get to know how someone just like them has gone through it before—not only that these people exist, but also how they felt, where they are now, and how things are changing across the globe.  

Where will my money go? 
Our current platform can accept written entries, but can't yet perform searches or organize results… It’s like a stand-in: it’s missing the meat—and a lot of it. We've gotten this far with the help of lawyers, software companies, designers, web developers, photographers, media consultants, bloggers, local nonprofits, and more. But we can't grow further without funding: skilled developers cost over $100/hour! We need your help!
Your money will go towards the development of the back-end “machine” we need to support our platform. It will organize the data, enable searches, and expand functionality. Your resources will enable the infrastructure necessary for this platform to exist. These resources will contribute to:


User Interface Design (it needs to look crazy good!)

Back-End Development (its a unique and complex platform. We need help!)

Custom Server Configuration (let's make it fast, shall we?)

Grassroots and Creative Outreach (getting the word out is key!)

By helping us to build this online interface, you'll help LGBTQ Youth access content they can relate to in a meaningful and personal way. To see themselves in stories will give them hope; knowing how others faced their own challenges will make them more resilient. They’ll get to know they are not alone, no matter where they are.
 
The contributor perks
We reward contributors with unique and limited run perks that our team will make, cook and craft, and they will always remind you of the important role you played in making this resource a reality. Click below and visit our gallery for images! 

We believe these to be superb perks, and there's something you should know about them: even though quite awesome, they fall (VERY) short of letting you know the full extent of our gratitude. A team bear hug would be a good start towards letting you know how thankful we are to have you onboard.
Stop for a second, and think of how sites like Google Maps, craigslist and reddit have truly changed how we live, think, and act. There is true potential for scalable, sustainable, and powerful change here. Every contribution helps us get closer to making it a tangible reality. Together, we can take it beyond our wildest dreams.
 If you believe that this platform will make a positive impact in the world, please show your support with even just a buck! Reading off those sixteen digits always go by faster than you expect :)

There are many ways to help - SHARING IS CARING!
We want to get info on this campaign to everyone cares: help us by sharing this page with friends, parents, your employer's LGBTQ group, your local LGBTQ center, your college campus' student-run organization—every little bit helps!

There are many other important ways in which you can make a powerful contribution and help us make it happen. Every sharing effort and donation matter a whole lot. We urge you to take a minute and:

Comment on our campaign page here.
Like and share our campaign and use indiegogo’s sharing tools. Share it with anyone with a heart! They don’t have to be gay, they just have to be human! Every single dollar, like, comment, and share counts.
Post our campaign page in Facebook Pages that you Like and are related to the LGBTQ movement
Like our Facebook Page

story:
The Real Life "Glee"

Meet Happiness, Inc. Show Ensemble, the varsity show choir at John F. Kennedy High School in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.  Happiness, Inc. is one of the nation's oldest and most well known high school show choirs and was founded with the opening of Kennedy High School in the fall of 1967.  Happiness, Inc. consists of 53 singer/dancers, 11 back-up band members, and a technical crew of 10.  These students, and a village of parents and teachers, have been working hard on their 2014 competition show since last July, setting their sights on the Show Choir Nationals Competition in Nashville, Tennessee this April.

It takes a tremendous amount of time, talent, and treasure just to produce a 20- minute show and fund the group's regular local competition schedule.  This year, group members hope to return to Nashville, attempting to reclaim the championship they won when they last appeared at the event in 2012.  These amazing students have put in the time, have shared their considerable talent, and have almost reached their "treasure" goal.  The student members of Happiness, Inc. are asking you to help them make it to the finish line, allowing them to perform onstage at the Grand Ole Opryhouse, the same historic stage as such fabulous performers as Carrie Underwood, George Jones, and Johnny Cash.

In this year's show, Happiness, Inc. pays tribute to the men and women of the US Armed Forces.  The show explores the challenges of war, what our men and women are fighting to protect, and closes with a rousing tribute using the themes of the Army, Navy, Air Force, and Marines. 

What We Need

Our goal for this campaign is $5,000.  This amount will put the group over the top of the amount they need to fund their trip. Producing a Happiness, Inc. show is an expensive endeavor.  While our school district offers the group a place to practice and a director, the district is unable to provide any financial assistance for the annual operating costs of the group.  When you add the costs of music arrangements, costuming, choreography and show design, transportation, contest registration, props, clinicians, and equipment maintenance, the financial resources necessary for show choir are quite substantial. Including the trip to Nashville, the Happiness kids needed to collect $110,000.  Through the payment of fees and a robust fundraising effort involving the kids and their parents, the group will crack the $105,000 mark.  They have done the bulk of the work and would be honored to have your help with this final amount.    

The Impact

Happiness, Inc. is one of eleven curricular choirs that form the Kennedy High School Vocal Music Department.  Nearly 200 students participate in three Kennedy show choirs.  Students are cast in these groups based on their desire and ability.  Financial assistance is available to any student and we use our fundraising efforts to help any family in need.  This year, we have a few more families in need than normal, which is the reason for this campaign.

Students describe the program as their home away from home.  For some kids, being in choir is the one place in their day that they can be themselves, free to express their thoughts and feelings in a caring, understanding environment.  Students learn about much more than music, singing and dancing.  They learn real world interpersonal skills that colleges and future employers value.  They learn how to work as followers and leaders.  They experience long-term goal setting and how to plan incremental goals along the way to measure progress.  Students leave the program at Kennedy and become leaders in colleges, churches, workplaces and communities across the country.  They get their first taste of the real world working their hearts out on the Kennedy stage. 

Any funding raised over the $5,000 goal will go directly in to our student assistance fund which will help future Kennedy students participate in our program despite their financial situation.

The Yellow Happiness Jacket

The most visible symbol of Happiness, Inc. is the yellow jacket that all official group members wear throughout their time in the group.  The jackets got their start in 1973 when then director Jim Kimmel was seeking ways to bring a sense of pride and reward for the excellent work that Happiness had achieved and enjoyed.  Over the past 40 years, the yellow jacket has become one of the show choir world's most recognized "team uniform."  Jim Kimmel's vision for the jacket still holds true today:

- the jacket is worn as a sign of our hard work, humility, and honesty

- the jacket is worn proudly as a sign of group unity and purpose

- the jacket represents our best efforts and the excellence that results

- the jacket is to be worn only by official group members

Each summer, new group members are presented their jackets by veteran members in a ceremony involving group members and their families.

Happiness members give back to their community.  Yellow jackets have been seen recently helping local families with storm recovery, collecting food donations for local food pantries, adopting needy families for holiday gift giving, packing back packs with school supplies for local students as they start the school year, and making sure area children are warm in the winter by donating coats, hats, mittens and scarves to a Coats for Kids campaign.

When you see a yellow jacket, you can be assured that good things are happening!  

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is in a position to contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!  If you think Happiness, Inc. is worthy of help:

  • Help us get the word out by sharing this link on your Facebook page or Twitter feed.
  • Do you know alumni, alumni parents or grandparents? Let them know about our efforts.

Thank you so much for your time!
